PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.
The petition of the undersigned respectfully brings to your attention:
that there are individuals who have a conscientious objection to war because of their religious or general moral principles
and that the Parliament of this country has already recognised the right of such individuals not to have to participate in military service in time of war
and that all Australian taxpayers are required to contribute to military expenditure, regardless of their beliefs, through that part of their tax that is used for the Defence budget

Dear Senator Collins

On 30 August 1988, you wrote to the Department of Industrial Relations about the Committee's consideration of Public Service Determination No. 159 of 1988. In view of the Public Service Commissioner's role in making the Determination, the Department of Industrial Relations has agreed that I should reply to your letter.
Your letter raised a number of concerns which relate to the discretion in the Determination to withhold the early cessation payment which is authorised by the Determination.

The Explanatory Memorandum for the Determination mentions that the discretion to withhold the payment is included to avoid the problems which might arise if a large number of officers sought to retire at the same time. I think it is important to emphasise here that while the Determination provides a discretion to withhold the early cessation payment it does not remove the right of Flight Service and Air Traffic Control staff to retire with a pension under the Superannuation Act 1976 once they reach the age of 50 years. There could thus be cases where an officer would choose to proceed with early retirement even though that might cause considerable inconvenience for the employer. In such circumstances, it would seem reasonable that the officer not have access to the significant employer-financed benefits available under the early cessation scheme.

I recognise that in referring to ``the interests of the Service'' clause 5.1.2 of the Determination does not specify any more detailed criteria which the Chief Executive Officer of the Civil Aviation Authority should follow in deciding whether to withhold the early cessation payment. I would compare this with the situation under the Public Service Act 1922, where there are powers which are expressed to be exercised subject to the ``interests of the Service'' or ``the interests of the efficient administration of the Service''. Examples of this are sections 51 and 76W of the Act. In both cases, the Act does not set out more detailed criteria on which the judgment might be made. Similarly, I note that in response to a letter of 2 June 1987 from the then Chairman of your Committee, Public Service Board Determination 1983/10 was amended to delete references to `public interest' in favour of `in the interests of the Service'.

The Civil Aviation Authority has developed criteria for identifying those staff who should be given priority for retirement with the early cessation payment authorised by the Determination. The Authority's intention is that priority for retirement will be determined by a points system based on the sum of the age and length of relevant service of the eligible staff. Staff with the highest points, and who wish to retire, would be given priority. With the agreement of the relevant staff organization, the Authority proposes that this system would operate for a transitional period of approximately 3 years. While this points system may appear mechanical, it has the acceptance of staff and provides an objective means of avoiding the severe disruption which would result if all eligible staff were able to take the option of retirement upon introduction of the early cessation scheme. The same points system was used with success to phase-in the early cessation scheme for Air Traffic Control staff which commenced in January 1985.

The Determination does not specify an avenue of review for cases where an officer was not granted the early cessation payment. However, a decision under clause 5.1 (2) of the Determination to withhold the payment could be reviewed through a number of generally available to review mechanisms. The first option would be for the officer to seek review through the grievance provisions contained in Division 3 of Part III of the Public Service Regulations (regulations 82 to 86 inclusive). Under this process, the grievance would be reviewed in the employing agency. In the event that the officer was not satisfied with the outcome of the internal review, he or she could request investigation of the matter by the Merit Protection and Review Agency. The officer could also pursue the matter in accordance with the provisions of the Administrative Decisions (Judicial Review) Act 1977, which would allow the officer to seek a statement of reasons for a decision to withhold the early cessation payment and to seek review of the decision through the Federal Court.

Your final point concerns the reference in clause 5 of the Explanatory Memorandum to a review of the operation of the scheme after a period of 3 years. This review would relate primarily to the discretion in clause 5.1 (2) of the Determination to withhold the early cessation payment. The basis of the 3 year review period is that the Civil Aviation Authority and the relevant staff organization have agreed to work towards a target phase-in period of three years and will be meeting regularly to review progress towards that objective. In effect, then, the review referred to in the Explanatory Memorandum will be commenced as an ongoing exercise well before the scheme has been in operation for three years. Noting this, and that the phasing-in period could well be reduced or extended from the current three year target, we believe that it would, on balance, be preferable not to specify the three year period in the Determination.
I trust this information will overcome the concerns which have been identified by the Committee.
Yours sincerely

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce. It follows the rather dismissive reply he gave to a question from Senator Walters yesterday about the car plan. He seemed to push the question off on the basis that the matter had been reported in the Australian newspaper. I remind the Minister that, when he announced the car plan, he said in a statement on 29 May that there were four central aims to the car plan, two of which were to make it more efficient and to hold down the price of cars. I also refer the Minister to the fact that, since the introduction of the car plan, increases in prices of locally made vehicles have outstripped the consumer price index by a factor of about two to one, and that the price of a standard Ford vehicle, which I understand has the highest level of local content of any locally produced vehicle-that is the vehicle one would assume is least affected by the devaluation that the Minister referred to yesterday-has increased by almost 70 per cent over that same period. I ask the Minister: Does he regard the outcome with respect to car prices in Australia as satisfactory? Does he regard the outcome with regard to efficiency as satisfactory? If the answer is yes to either or both questions, by what measures does he claim that it is satisfactory, since Australian car buyers are still manifesting sticker shock at the very large price increases that have occurred under the Button car plan?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I never regard anything as particularly satisfactory. I regard the situation, firstly, in terms of the efficiency of the motor vehicle industry in Australia, as a vast improvement on what it was. In my answer to Senator Walters yesterday, I referred to the fact that for the first time in a very long time exports of motor vehicles and components from the motor vehicle industry are, I think it is fair to say, at their highest level ever, and have increased rapidly, and will increase a lot further next year. That is something of a test in an industry that is dependent on volume. Certainly in an industry where there is a close relationship between the component sector and the manufacturing sector, the improvement has been in both parts. On whether I regard it as satisfactory or not, of course, I would like it to be better, but I regard it as a considerable improvement on what has happened previously.

ANSWER.PARA: The second part of the question relates to price. Following the devaluation of the Australian dollar there were increases, as I said yesterday, in the price of imported vehicles and in the price of locally made vehicles, largely because of component content. I think Senator Chaney has refined that question a bit more today by referring to the Ford Falcon as being the car with the highest local content and saying that the effect of the component price increases following the devaluation should be less in a high local content car. That very much depends on the value, not the amount of imported components-their value in terms of total value of the components in the car; whether they are high cost items or not. However, following the devaluation I said publicly that there was probably some profit taking rather than market share motivation in some of the local producers and that was disappointing.

TALK.START.PARA: —You're not doing too well, John.
—Who is not doing too well?
—You're not doing too well.

—Both I and the Automotive Industry Authority made some comments about that at the time. I think the public discussion about the issue has directed motor vehicle companies' attention even more in recent months to the question of price. With new models on the road, such as the new Commodore and the new Falcon, the market will be more competitive. With tariffs lowered, as they have been again, the market will become more competitive and if that does not follow through in price effects by the early 1990s, then I think the companies will lose--
—By when?

—By the early 1990s. I am talking about the tariff. Does the honourable senator understand what the tariff is? She nods, but I bet she does not know what it is. If this has not occurred by the early 1990s, the local producers will lose market share, unless they can pick it up in exports. That is very clear.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I thank the Minister for his answer. I note that he included in it a reference to the fact that it is a test in an industry which is dependent on volume and of course volumes have fluctuated considerably over the last few years. Is the Minister saying, therefore, that as far as he and the Government are concerned the plan is on track?

—Senator Chaney put his first question in terms of whether I was satisfied and I said, `No, not satisfied, but pleased that there has been considerable improvement'. The lead times in this industry are very long and that is why the car plan is running over a period of seven years. Since the plan was announced on 29 May 1984 there have been enormous factors which have intervened in terms of the devaluation of the dollar and so on, but in terms of changing the structure of the industry in order to produce more efficiently and in the longer term at lower costs, the answer is yes.

—I ask the Minister for Resources whether it is true that next month the iron ore producing companies will commence negotiations for supply contracts to Japan. Is the Minister able to say what the prospects are for iron ore sales in the coming year? ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank Senator McKiernan for his question. I wish to advise the Senate that I am conducting a round of discussions with iron ore companies on trends in the market and their expectations for price and tonnage of iron ore exports for next year. I have talked already to Hamersley Iron Pty Ltd, Mount Newman Mining Co. Pty Ltd and Robe River Iron Associates. I will be speaking to Goldsworthy Mining Ltd next Monday.

ANSWER.PARA: The world iron ore industry has been badly squeezed in the past few years with steel demand flat and increased supplies of ore from other countries. Between 1982 and 1988 nominal prices in United States dollars for sales into Japan fell by 29 per cent. That amounted to a reduction of 36 per cent in real Australian dollar terms. Moreover, there has been a price increase only once in the past six years. Those market conditions have hurt all of our producers. The Australian industry has survived because it has adapted effectively to the challenges and constraints it has faced.

I am pleased to advise the Senate that, on the basis of my discussions with the companies and analysis from my Department, I believe that we have every reason to expect solid increases in the prices we receive for our iron ore next year. Iron ore has always been one of the mainstays of our resources sector. Its position will be enhanced next year by relatively tight supply conditions indicated by reductions in ore stockpiles around the world, by the continuing growth of the world economy, by the particularly strong growth in the international steel industry and, last but not least, by the excellent reputation for security of supply, reliability in shipments and quality of output which the Australian mines have built up.

That reputation has been built up painstakingly over many years. I pay special tribute to the iron ore unions in the Pilbara which have reduced the level of industrial disputation significantly and which have worked effectively through the consultative mechanisms established in the Western Australian Iron Ore Industry Consultative Council. We cannot now put those gains in jeopardy, especially as we are now in a position to start to reap the rewards of the hard work which we have put in over the years. I therefore urge the iron ore unions to maintain the record they have set in industrial harmony, in improved productivity and in further developing the iron ore industry on which Western Australia and Australia generally have long relied.

I therefore look forward to the coming negotiations in Japan and Europe with optimism and confidence. The negotiations are a matter for the companies concerned. My confidence reflects, in part, the Government's assessment of the skills and experience which the companies will bring to the negotiations. The Government will watch the negotiations closely. We have reserve powers available in regard to the export of iron ore, but I can say now that the Government believes that the companies are likely to effect a negotiated outcome which is satisfactory not only to them but to Australia, to our current account, to our export performance and to the overall health of the Australian economy.

We cannot actually start paying people until we are told they are working. Senator Sheil's statement yesterday completely misunderstood and distorted what I said. This is the second time in about four weeks that I have had National Party members not thoroughly reading supplementary answers and then shooting their mouths off.

In regard to the second part of the question, Senator Sheil asserted that there were still teething problems with the computer system. He puts no current evidence forward. In good faith I have had investigations made. We talked, in October, to the people currently running the system. They inform me in good faith that the system is now running well. That is not to say that there are not disputes. There are always disputes when it comes to travel allowance and salary claims, whether the system is running well or not. But it is no use going back to the teething problems of August and July-I admit, and I put it on the record, that there will be problems with a new computer system-and claiming that I was misleading the Senate on 15 or 16 October when I said that the system was working adequately.
The third part of Senator Colston's question referred to Senator Sheil's press release. I will quote just part of it, but I am happy to table the lot. It stated:
Outside Parliament Senator Sheil described the situation as `incredible'.
`Fancy a woman having to wait seven weeks to be paid,' he said. `If it happened in the private sector the employer would be arrested.

Let us look at the second case that Senator Sheil was involved with. On 11 July 1988 the Department of Administrative Services was finally notified that a person had been working for Senator Sheil from 13 April 1987. Sixty-five weeks after the person had started employment that person contacted the Department of Administrative Services. That was the first time we knew that she even existed. The only reason for contacting the Department of Administrative Services was that travel was required. We informed that person, `We cannot give you a travel document unless we know that you are on the payroll'. I must say that it occurred to the Department that it was a little strange that someone who had been appointed 65 weeks before had not been paid and we had not heard one whimper about it.

The first we heard from Senator Sheil on this matter was, again, on 10 August 1988-70 weeks after he had employed someone. Yet Senator Sheil has had the gall to put out a press release saying that if someone has not been paid seven weeks after commencing employment people should be arrested. What should happen to Senator Sheil? Seventy weeks after he employed someone we were finally told by him that he was employing that person. We now have a claim for something like $25,000 in back pay. He has the gall to say that I have misled this chamber, when I clearly did not. He has the gall to put out a press release saying that if there were a seven-week pay delay in private industry someone would be arrested. Yet Senator Sheil has taken 70 weeks to inform the Department of a person's employment.

Often, when I was the Minister in charge of this area, if a person's pay was two weeks late people would be trooping around to my office with a noose. Apparently in this case Senator Sheil employed someone who was very well off, who could afford not to be paid for 70 weeks. When we were notified of this matter there was a slight delay in starting the payment for that staff member, because we were a little puzzled. But that has been rectified. Senator Sheil notified us on 10 August and on, I think, 1 September that staff member was paid from 10 August. The rest of the claims will have to be sorted out when Senator Sheil responds to our correspondence on this matter.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Community Services and Health. It would help if my microphone were on.
—Senator Haines, apparently that microphone is not working. Could you try again?
—Mr President, if my microphone is not working, and apparently it is not, is it acceptable for me to move to another seat?
—You stupid twit! Of course you cannot hear me; the microphone is not on.
—Order! I suggest that Senator Haines use another microphone.
—Thank you.
—Mr President, I raise a point of order. It is not appropriate to refer to another senator in this chamber as a stupid twit. I ask that the honourable senator withdraw.
—Order! It is unparliamentary. I must say that I could not hear it. If that remark was made, I ask that it be withdrawn.
—The remark was certainly made, Mr President, and I withdraw it. Mr President, I am not going to dance around this chamber trying to find a microphone that works.
—Order! I suggest that interjections cease so that we can hear Senator Haines's question.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Community Services and Health. Is the Government aware of chronic fatigue syndrome (CFS) and its symptoms of persistent exhaustion, depression, inability to concentrate, joint pains, headache and memory loss? I would suggest that all of these affect the Opposition, except that I would probably be ruled out of order. Is it correct that as many as 16,000 people in Australia are reputed to be suffering from chronic fatigue syndrome? Is the Minister aware of the toxicology study being conducted by a group of New South Wales east coast health professionals, including Dr Mark Donohue, Dr Joachim Fluhrer and Mr William Vayda, covering CFS sufferers? Given that the first 41 samples of blood of CFS sufferers sent to the United States by this group show markedly abnormal levels of toxic chemicals-chloroform, DDT and hexachlorobenzene-at levels up to 20 times the average level for people in the United States, will the Government be examining the results of the preliminary study to be presented by Dr Donohue on 5 November at the Natural Health Society's convention? Is it correct that no disposal facilities for hexachlorobenzene exist in Australia, and can the Government explain why such high levels of DDT are being found in blood samples when this chemical has been banned in Australia?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government is aware of the chronic fatigue syndrome. In fact, I had the unfortunate and unpleasant experience of learning from one of my close friends that she suffered from the syndrome.
—The Government is suffering from chronic fatigue at the moment.

—The Government is suffering from chronic enthusiasm at the moment to get on with the job; it is the Opposition that is fatigued. If the level of interjections is any example, it is very fatigued indeed. Let me return to the subject, because this is one of the most unrecognised syndromes in Australia and indeed in the world. One of the problems for sufferers of it is that because their symptoms are unrecognised there is a tremendous overlay of trauma and the attitude is taken that sufferers are lazy or slothful, that they are always sleeping and never alert. People get dismissed from employment because of that. There is a high suicide rate among the 16,000 sufferers in Australia, and indeed a high suicide rate amongst CFS sufferers generally. From that point of view it is a syndrome that probably needs much more public recognition and understanding, and more attention to what levels and forms of treatment can be given to overcome it.

ANSWER.PARA: I was not aware of the study referred to by Senator Haines, but I am absolutely sure that Dr Blewett, the Minister for Community Services and Health, is aware of it. Senator Haines asks whether the Government will be taking an interest in the outcome of the study. The Government takes an interest in the outcome of studies of this nature and I have no reason to believe that we would not take a close interest in the outcome of this study. Since Senator Haines has drawn it to my attention, I will ensure that that is the case.

I do not know whether or not there is a hexachlorobenzene disposal facility in Australia. I will check that point and reply to the honourable senator later. I cannot explain, because I am not familiar with the study, why high levels of DDT and other chemicals are being found in the blood of the study group Senator Haines refers to. I will certainly examine those things and get back to her. This question serves a useful purpose not only because it raises the issues it does but because it focuses on chronic fatigue syndrome, something that deserves much more public attention in community and preventive medicine in Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I thank the Minister for his answer. I point out that doctors in this area are apparently being accused by the Department of Community Services and Health of overservicing because of the number of pathology tests required to get to the heart of the matter. Either before or after the Government has investigated the situation, will it please call off the Health Department and allow the patients to be paid for the pathology tests that are being undertaken?

—I cannot accept that the Health Department is victimising doctors for overservicing in this area. I will examine that allegation and reply to it in due course. We are, of course, concerned about doctors who abuse Medicare by overservicing. It is a problem which the Department and the Government are concerned about.
—It is a problem that results from the nature of Medicare.

—That is ridiculous. The honourable senator would have imposed on ordinary Australians an excessive charge for access to medical treatment. One of the greatest reforms this Government has made is to introduce Medicare and reduce the cost of health treatment for ordinary Australians and give ordinary Australians access to proper health care. Because of that system there is an abuse by overservicing. I would be alarmed and concerned if doctors treating this particular syndrome were being dealt with as if they were overservicing. That would need to be segregated. We will maintain our approach to overservicing but I will examine this allegation.

—I refer the Minister for Justice to the penetration of Australian society by narcotic drugs which is a matter of concern to all thinking Australians. Can the Minister provide the Senate with details of some of the more important recent drug seizures and arrests by the Australian Federal Police (AFP)?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Maguire does raise a matter of concern to all Australians. I know that the Joint Parliamentary Committee on the National Crime Authority is itself conducting a comprehensive investigation into the whole question of drug abuse in Australia and its relationship to law enforcement, criminality and other related aspects. I am sure it will provide the Senate, indeed the whole Parliament, with some very useful information and suggestions as to the way in which our society can cope with this phenomenon in the future. In the meantime, the Australian Federal Police has been given a specific charter and role to fulfil its function as the premier law enforcement agency of the Commonwealth to concentrate and focus, amongst other things, on the question of drug trafficking in Australia. From the point of view of the Federal Police that mainly focuses on the importation of drugs to Australia.

ANSWER.PARA: It is an opportune time for the honourable senator to ask this question-I know it was unrehearsed-as it coincides with the ninth anniversary of the formation of the Australian Federal Police. I know that Senator Hill as the shadow Minister will join me in congratulating the Federal Police on achieving its ninth anniversary.

TALK.START.PARA: —I certainly do.

—And I have no doubt that he would agree with me that it is, in its refocusing and reorganising, helping to achieve the objectives which have been set for it, particularly by my predecessor the Special Minister of State, Mr Mick Young, who gave the Federal Police a charter which enables it to concentrate its resources on the sorts of matters of concern to Senator Maguire.

ANSWER.PARA: Not only has the Federal Police developed an expertise in relation to combating drug trafficking, but also it needs to be acknowledged that there is a new ethos, a new understanding, amongst all the law enforcement agencies in Australia-whether they be Federal law enforcement agencies such as the National Crime Authority, or State or Northern Territory law enforcement agencies-that cooperation is the order of the day, that criminals themselves do not have any regard to State or international boundaries--

TALK.START.PARA: —The record has not been too good.

—I will give the honourable senator some instances to rebut that interjection which I think is somewhat unworthy. Nevertheless, I will take it up. For example, in March 1988 two persons were arrested in relation to a conspiracy to import heroin. This was the result of an AFP investigation in Perth which was conducted in cooperation with the Thai Office of the Narcotics Control Board. Further investigations, arranged through the AFP liaison officer, led to Thai authorities recovering approximately two kilograms of heroin. The international cooperative aspects needs to be emphasised. In June this year a joint AFP-Australian Customs Service operation was conducted with the assistance of the New South Wales Water Police. Three vessels were intercepted off Sydney Harbour carrying approximately 3.2 tonnes of cannabis. Ten persons were arrested.

ANSWER.PARA: I could go on and on. I was not going to, but I think I will in the light of Senator Hill's interjection. In July 1988 the Australian Customs Service located approximately one kilogram of cocaine on a United States national at Sydney (Kingsford-Smith) Airport. Subsequent investigations by the AFP resulted in the arrest of three persons. Again, only last month, the AFP seized approximately 5.15 kilograms of heroin in the possession of a Singapore national. The seizure was a result of an investigation conducted with close liaison between the AFP and the Singapore Central Narcotics Bureau. Only last weekend the Australian Customs Service found approximately two kilograms of heroin on a Pakistani national at Sydney Airport. The man was handed over to the AFP and he assisted the AFP in a controlled delivery of the drugs which led to the subsequent arrest of a second person. I believe that this is a very important categorisation of some successful seizures.

TALK.START.PARA: —How much gets through? Ninety-five per cent gets through.
—Of course, a lot gets through. I do not know what the percentage is. I do not think anyone can say what the percentage is.
—That is the tragedy.

—It is a tragedy in so far as it hits our streets and leads to the degradation and the death of young Australians in particular. That is why not only are we trying to conduct, through Federal and State law enforcement agency cooperation, the fight against this drug trafficking but also, in cooperation with the Health Ministers-I know that Senator Peter Baume would have a particular interest in this-on the Ministerial Council for Drug Strategy, we are trying to formulate a comprehensive approach through education, health and law enforcement aspects. I believe that we are beginning to succeed. I thank Senator Maguire for his interest in the matter. I hope that honourable senators will appreciate that, on this ninth anniversary of the Australian Federal Police, they are indeed performing very well in this field.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: AUSTRALIAN BICENTENNIAL AUTHORITY: EXHIBITION OF MACEDONIAN ANTIQUITIES

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to whichever Minister represents the Minister responsible for the Australian Bicentennial Authority (ABA). I ask whichever Minister that is whether he or she can confirm that the Prime Minister has told the Australian Bicentennial Authority that it must contribute $950,000 towards the cost of an exhibition of Macedonian antiquities being brought to Australia. Is this the same exhibition which was nearly derailed when the Government insisted that the term `Macedonian' not be used in the title of the exhibition because of the alleged offence that it might give to some ethnic groups in Australia? Is the $950,000 which the ABA has been instructed to give in support of this exhibition to be taken away from a foundation marked for the support of Australian youth which was going to be established by the Authority? Finally, is the Minister aware that the Authority has just refused to provide financial assistance for the Sydney Symphony Orchestra to tour the United States of America and that the Sydney Symphony Orchestra will tour the United States on a sponsorship given by a Japanese computer company? Is the Government prepared to explain why the ABA has been instructed to provide $950,000 towards this exhibition and how much of that is a consequence of the Government's earlier decision to try to derail the exhibition coming to Australia in the first place?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —Because the question relates to an alleged action by the Prime Minister and because some aspects clearly involve other Ministers and departments I will endeavour to answer the question. In so far as I cannot, I will obtain further information for Senator Puplick.

ANSWER.PARA: I am advised that the Government of Greece has offered an exhibition of antiquities from Macedonia as a gesture for Australia's Bicentenary and in recognition of the close relations between our two countries. The Prime Minister asked the Bicentennial Authority to provide some financial support for the exhibition. I am further advised that the Chairman of the Bicentennial Authority agreed to provide the $950,000 referred to by Senator Puplick in his question. The exhibition, it is hoped, will be opened by the President of Greece in Melbourne on 25 November this year and will then visit Sydney and Brisbane. It is said to be a very fine exhibition, which will be of interest to many thousands of Australians, and the largest exhibition of Macedonian antiquities ever to leave Greece.

I am unable to answer that part of the question which related to whether the use of the word `Macedonia' was at some stage regarded as offensive or not to some ethnic communities. I will obtain an answer on that question for Senator Puplick.

I will also obtain an answer as to whether the Bicentennial Authority refused a request for funding from the Sydney Symphony Orchestra for its tour of North America. I am delighted that the tour is apparently taking place and I must say that I do not find it a matter of concern that that tour is in fact funded by a Japanese computer corporation.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Could the Minister either inform me or endeavour to obtain information as to when it was that Mr Kirk, the Chairman of the Australian Bicentennial Authority, agreed to the instruction or request to contribute the $950,000, and whether or not the board of the authority was ever consulted in this matter?

—I have already answered in terms of saying it was a request from the Prime Minister. I just want to get the terminology correct, senator. In so far as the second part of the supplementary question is concerned, I will obtain an answer.
—My question is directed to the Minister for Local Government. Has the Minister given priority to Aboriginal councils following the revelations of the Toomelah report?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Reynolds Sen The Hon M.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes. The Toomelah report by Justice Einfeld, I am sure, will have shocked many Australians and I suppose the result was to ensure that Federal, State and local government work more effectively together to ensure good conditions for Aboriginal communities. In actual fact, the Office of Local Government and the Department of Aboriginal Affairs had already initiated moves to establish an interdepartmental committee to work on the needs of Aboriginal councils and that committee has been in operation now for over 12 months.

ANSWER.PARA: Senator Childs will be aware that, for the first time, in 1987 a total of 73 Aboriginal councils-42 in the Northern Territory and 31 in Queensland-were entitled to grants under the local government financial assistance grants legislation and the Office of Local Government has sponsored a study by a consultant in Queensland to ensure that those resources are effectively allocated to Aboriginal communities. We want to be sure that Aboriginal communities are getting their rightful share of the financial assistance grants, and the first stage of that was implemented in this year's distribution.

Furthermore, the New South Wales Local Government and Shires Association had indicated its interest and its concern about the way Aboriginal communities on the fringes of country towns were considered and it received a grant from the Office of Local Government to look at improving relations and getting better cooperation and greater sensitivity to the needs of Aboriginal councils in country areas.

I suppose one of the problems had been that far too many councils assume that other departments are looking after those councils. They are very happy to count Aborigines in regard to population statistics for their local grants commissions, but they are not always as speedy in creating services for those communities. Aborigines, wherever they live, are entitled to full services from their local councils. They are also entitled to additional services that are the responsibility of the Department of Aboriginal Affairs and a number of other State and Federal departments.

I think the work that was done by the New South Wales Local Government and Shires Association will go a long way towards ensuring that country councils in New South Wales particularly-and I am hoping that councils in other parts of the country will take note of the report-ensure that there is a better relationship and that councils work very sensitively with their Aboriginal communities. I know that in north Queensland, in my former council of Townsville, we employed an Aboriginal liaison officer to ensure that there was a person within local government who could monitor and maintain contact with Aboriginal people to ensure that they were aware of their rights and entitlements under local government.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Consumer Affairs. Has the Minister seen the article in the August 1988 edition of Current Affairs Bulletin by Professor Alan Tyree entitled `Who Pays? The Law and Electronic Funds Transfer', in which the effectiveness of the `Recommended Procedures to Govern the Relationship between the Users and Providers of Electronic Funds Transfer Systems' is questioned? Is the Government satisfied with the operation of the recommended procedures? Does the Government consider it satisfactory that, in cases of disputed transactions between an institution and a cardholder, the burden of proof effectively falls entirely on the cardholder, the party with generally little or no capacity to verify his or her claim? Has the Government considered adopting the system in use in New Zealand to resolve such disputes? Given the Government's promise that a review of the operation of the recommended procedures would be completed by about March this year, when can consumers expect to see the results of that review?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank Senator Vanstone for a timely question. The question of electronic funds transfers, the recommended procedures and also the level of implementation of those procedures has been an item on the agenda of this Government for, as Senator Vanstone said, some time now. In fact, one of the first tasks I took on as Minister in this portfolio was to meet with industry and to discuss the whole level of the adequacy of the procedures and their implementation. I did so in the course of the review conducted by the Government and a working group of officials of this Government, which working group is intended to report later this year. In fact, the report is expected by the end of November; if not, the start of December.

ANSWER.PARA: However, even though that working group of officials has been continuing its deliberations and in doing so obviously looking at the degree of compliance, at a recent meeting of State and Federal Ministers held in Melbourne on 29 July this matter was also raised by a number of Ministers, including me. As a consequence of that item on the agenda it was further agreed that State and Federal Ministers would take a keener interest in the particular review going on. Mr Roper, the Victorian Minister for Consumer Affairs, is also spearheading discussions with industry to ensure that we achieve by the end of this year not only sufficient enforcement of the procedures but also a sufficient level of protection to consumers under the procedures.

I have also discussed the matter with the Trade Practices Commission, with the intention that, together with the Trade Practices Commission, we may at the end of the day be able to achieve a degree of enforcement in respect to a self-regulatory code, a degree of enforcement that will also give added protection to consumers.

So the short answer to Senator Vanstone's question is that not only is the Government aware of the particular problem, but a number of responses have been initiated by me in this portfolio to try to accommodate the particular problem and the whole range of issues involved with it.

Senator Vanstone raised two specific items in the course of her general inquiry about this whole area. One was in respect of an article that appeared earlier this month. I have not seen that article, but I am sure that most of the problems pointed out in that article are problems that have been brought home to me. The New Zealand experience is one which I am sure the committee spearheaded by Mr Roper is looking at. I will be meeting very shortly with the New Zealand Minister responsible for consumer affairs and one of the items that I have on my agenda to discuss with her is compliance in this area.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the Minister for Consumer Affairs aware of recent press statements which indicate that the antisocial toys are still being sold by some retailers despite an agreement to remove the toys from sale? Is the Minister aware that the Australian Federation of Consumer Organisations (AFCO) is reported to have conducted a survey which indicates that the self-regulation agreement with the toy industry has been unsuccessful? What steps is the Minister taking to rectify this?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —The question that Senator Devereux raises is one that has been of concern to governments for some time, not only on a Federal level but also on a State level. In fact, a Victorian committee of inquiry into antisocial toys which was released in June this year, and which committee reported to its Minister in February of this year, advised that there was reasonable evidence to suggest that there were casual links between antisocial toys and psychological harm, particularly to children. So it is an area of concern to government.

ANSWER.PARA: We have had in place for the last seven to eight months a code of self-regulation with the toy industry. The toys basically covered by this particular code are those toys which are ghoulish in nature and which depict children and other human beings in different states of deformity, injury, mutilation, and so on. They are the toys that I think parents throughout the country have been concerned about in terms of their effect on children. The Government's response, as I said, has been one of self-regulation and, together with the toy industry, we have had a substantial degree of compliance with self-regulation. Over the last seven months we have had 31 instances of breaches of the self-regulatory undertaking given by the toy industry; each of those has been followed up successfully. The Victorian inquiry into this area recommended that we proceed with self-regulation across the whole spectrum of three sorts of toys-war toys, toys of violence and victim toys. As the Senate knows, Senator Devereux asked about the last one-victim toys.

In terms of whether the Government proceeds with a regime of self-regulation, it is fair to say that that regime is very much on trial at the moment. AFCO reported that there had been substantial breaches, particularly in the eastern States, of the self-regulatory code. What the Government has done in response to AFCO's report is on three different levels. We have raised the issue once again with the Australian Toy Association Pty Ltd. It has undertaken to contact all its members, urging on them the need to withdraw these toys from the market. Secondly, the Government has indicated that each complaint of a breach of the code will be followed up, and we are doing so at the moment. Thirdly, we will be contacting all importers of these toys to ensure that they also comply with the code.

In essence, we recognise that there is a problem in this area, and the question of whether we maintain self-regulation or proceed to a tighter enforcement regime ultimately will depend on the effectiveness of self-regulation over the next five months.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade. Has he been able to ascertain from Vietnam information about whether two Buddhist monks arrested in 1984 with other Buddhist scholars, namely, Pham Van Thuong, a philosopher, writer and teacher, as well as being a monk, whose Buddhist name is Thich Tue Sy, and Le Manh That, an eminent scholar whose Buddhist name is Thich Tri Sieu, were in fact condemned to death in September or early October this year in court in Hanoi? If that is the case, will the Government make representations to the Government of Vietnam to, at the very least, secure the commutation of the death sentence?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —We have learned of the trial in Ho Chi Minh City between 28 and 30 September of 21 people charged with subversive activities, two of whom, Thich Tue Sy and Thich Tri Sieu, were condemned to death and the other 19 sentenced to terms of imprisonment. Following earlier reports relating to the imprisonment of Thich Tri Sieu, I raised the matter of his particular case with the Vietnamese Vice-Minister Co in New York when I met him a few days ago, seeking information which he was unable to give me at the time about the circumstances of his imprisonment.

ANSWER.PARA: Following confirmation this morning-I have only just received it-of the death sentence on these two Buddhist monks, I have issued urgent instructions to our ambassador in Hanoi to take this matter up with the appropriate Vietnamese authorities, making clear, as we have in a number of other instances around the world, the Australian Government's abhorrence of, and complete opposition to, capital punishment.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs. I ask the Minister to note that the Australian Government, with the support of the Australian Democrats, recently passed through parliament a motion which acknowledged that Australia was occupied by Aboriginals and Torres Strait Islanders for thousands of years before British settlement; that the Government is now legislating a preamble to the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission Bill which recognises dispossession of this land without compensation; and also that dispossession has been progressive throughout the last 200 years and still continues. Can the Minister, therefore, say, firstly, whether Aboriginal and Islander people have ever been consulted about Australia's policy of active immigration? If so, do Aboriginals and Islanders approve or disapprove of this policy? If they have not been consulted, why have they not been, and is it the Government's view that Aboriginals and Torres Strait Islanders have no right to a voice on how many more people should come in to occupy their land? Finally, if this is not the Government's view, will the Government now consult with Aboriginals and Torres Strait Islanders about how many more immigrants will come?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: IMMIGRATION, LOCAL GOVERNMENT AND ETHNIC AFFAIRS

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Coulter, in general terms, was kind enough to give me an indication of some of the subject matter here. I was kind enough to get an answer, which I have subsequently lost. But let me go to the three points he raises. As to consultation, the Government set up the Committee to Advise on Australia's Immigration Policy headed by Dr Stephen FitzGerald in July 1987. It, of course, went right around Australia and made itself available to hear a variety of points of view. Representatives of the Aboriginal communities in Adelaide, Perth and Darwin addressed that Committee and put views to it. Secondly, of course, Ms Eve Fesl is a member of the Office of the Advisory Council on Multicultural Affairs, and again is a person who has an expert knowledge in these areas and not only is available to receive those views but also puts those views very forcefully. In general, I have to say that opportunity has been given to representatives of the Aboriginal community to put views on the question of immigration.

ANSWER.PARA: Senator Coulter asked: What are their views? I suggest that a variety of views have been received from time to time, some put in more colourful language than others by employees of this Government at the head of department level. However, for the most part there is a recognition that an immigration policy will be a continuing feature into the future and not necessarily opposition to it. Senator Coulter asked whether these representatives and the Aboriginal communities have a right to put views on immigration. They have an absolute right to put those views. We, in our consultation round in September, made ourselves available to talk to any particular group. I must say that on my tour around Australia no group representing the Aboriginal community availed itself of that opportunity. But I think, on the whole, I have made myself available to any group that wants to put a view to me about the FitzGerald report and future immigration policy, and I will continue to leave my door open to those sorts of views.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories. Has the Minister's attention been drawn to an article headed `Coalition split on forest policy' which appeared in today's Australian? Does the Government intend to remove any Australian properties from the World Heritage List? If so, how would this be done? Has the Minister's attention been drawn to a pledge by the Leader of the National Party of Australia, Ian Sinclair, on 8 October that a future Liberal-National Party coalition government would consider delisting certain Australian World Heritage properties? What effects will such a pledge, if carried out, have on current government policy on this matter?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: ARTS, SPORT, THE ENVIRONMENT, TOURISM AND TERRITORIES

TALK.START.PARA: —I am aware of the article to which Senator Jones refers. The article, by Suzanne Houweling, which was in this morning's Australian, said:

ANSWER.PARA: The federal Liberal and National parties yesterday appeared irrevocably split over a central element of their new environment policy, released on Tuesday.

It did not take very long-it took all of two days. I am not at all surprised about that. Senator Jones asked whether the Government intended to take any properties off the World Heritage List. Of course the answer to that is no. Not only do we not intend to remove any from the list, we also intend to add some to the list.

TALK.START.PARA: —Which ones?

—I am about to tell Senator Boswell. He need not worry, he is about to figure heavily in this answer, so he should just remain patient. When one looks at what the Government would do to add to the list, as distinct from removing properties from it, the first place one must look at is north Queensland. Honourable senators opposite know a bit about north Queensland. They know nothing about what the people think and they know nothing of its ecology, but at least they do know where it is on the map-at least I think they do. When I look at the wet tropics of north Queensland I have to say that the statements of Mr Sinclair indicate that he has pledged the opposite to Senator Puplick's policy.

ANSWER.PARA: What did Senator Puplick do? He was absolutely unable to face the hard question, that is: what do you do when faced with an intransigent State government which will not do the right thing? Again, he was faced with the National Party overruling him. But of course, Senator Puplick is used to being overruled on environment matters. If ever I were to be overruled by Senator Boswell I could not wake up the next morning and think anything of myself! That would be the ultimate disgrace! Having said that, I know what Senator Puplick has now told us he will do and how the Liberals will go about it. Neither members with family nor single members receive disturbance allowance on posting overseas; nor do they receive a removal entitlement if posted for a period of less than six months.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —I present to the Senate a further communication from the Aboriginal Development Commission in response to the inquiry which I made following Senator Boswell's question yesterday.

INTERJECT.PARA: In accordance with the procedures laid down by the resolution of the Senate on 25 February 1988, Senator Chaney has written to me raising a matter of privilege. The matter relates to the resolution of the Aboriginal Development Commission which I obtained from the Commission and tabled yesterday in response to the question put to me by Senator Boswell. Under the resolutions of the Senate I am required to determine whether a motion to refer the matter to the Committee of Privileges should have precedence of other business, having regard to certain criteria. The criteria refer to the principle that the Senate's power to deal with contempts should be used only where it is necessary to provide responsible protection against improper acts tending substantially to obstruct the Senate, its committees and senators, and to the existence of any other remedy.

I do not believe that I can properly make a determination on this matter until I have given consideration to the additional material forwarded to me by the Aboriginal Development Commission which I have presented to the Senate today. I will therefore report my determination to the Senate on the next day of sitting.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the statement.

Mr President, I wish to speak briefly on this matter. I can understand your believing that you are unable to report on a letter which I delivered to you just before the Senate began sitting this morning because additional material has been put in your hands in the course of Question Time. I acknowledge the difficulty that you face.

The reason I wrote to you as a matter of urgency this morning and intended to ask you a question on the matter during Question Time, but could not do so because you indicated that you would be making a further statement, is that the issue is one of immediate importance. It is of immediate importance because the Senate Estimates Committee E will be sitting later today and dealing with, amongst other things, the estimates of the Department of Aboriginal Affairs and the Aboriginal Development Commission (ADC). I do not think that any observer of Aboriginal affairs in Australia at present would not believe that the game is being played fairly hard. The very difficult task which has been undertaken by the Government in respect of the total replacement of the existing administrative arrangements with an Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission, which will have an elected, controlling element, and a totally new approach to the delivery of services in this extremely complex area which is littered with some successes and many failures, is a matter of very great public importance.

In recent months we have seen the sacking of the bulk of the Board of the Aboriginal Development Commission in circumstances where the Commission was clearly resisting the Government's proposals. I remind the Senate that that Commission was put in place in a form which followed an extensive and lengthy process of consultation, about which no doubts were ever raised. That consultation was conducted very much at arms length from the political process. I divorced myself from that direct negotiation and put it in the hands of people with no vested political or other interest and I believe that the structure that was put in place was, at that time anyway, representative of the views of Aboriginal people.

The Minister has now reconstituted the Aboriginal Development Commission with people who, it is my understanding, have moved a motion of no confidence in the Chairman of the Commission under circumstances which are directly relevant to the matter which I raised with you as a matter of privilege today, namely, her appearance before the Senate Committee. Again, Mr President, I do not wish to raise matters where I am not in a position to finally substantiate a view, but I think that the likelihood of pressure being brought to bear on people in this matter is very real indeed. The concern of the Opposition and, I would hope, the concern of all senators would be to ensure that the Senate and its committees, both the Estimates Committee and the Select Committee, have the best possible access to the facts. I do not doubt that there will be disputes about facts and in the end, of course, there will be significant differences of judgment about what to do with whatever facts can be determined. But for what is a most complex and difficult process to be in any way sullied by attempts to suppress information, to prevent people, whether they have an interest or not, from freely putting information and views before instruments of the Senate would be a national scandal. The Opposition is extremely serious in its determination to see that this matter is dealt with in a full and fair way.

I wanted to speak on this motion because decisions will be made, no doubt, over the next 24 hours about who appears before the Estimates Committee. It is the clear view of the Opposition that it would be quite inadequate for the Estimates Committee to proceed without the assistance, for example, of Mrs Shirley McPherson and Mr O'Brien and whatever other public servants or ADC representatives are thought by the Government to be able to give factual and clear information to the Committee. So I emphasise to the Senate the serious view that the Opposition takes of the matter that I wrote to you, Mr President, about this morning. If there is any suggestion that any improper pressure is being applied to people, I can assure you that we will greet that with outrage and we will take every parliamentary action which is open to us to ensure that it is stopped.

In a very hurried and casual conversation with the Minister for Justice (Senator Tate) who represents the Government in this place on this matter I think it is fair to say that he said, `Of course we all have a common view', or words to that effect, `that we would want full information to be available'. I say to the Minister that I welcome that sort of response from him. I trust that the Minister would have exactly the same view as the general view which I have expressed in this place and that the Australian Democrats would also have the same view. I do not think anybody in this place would in any way doubt the difficulty of the exercise that is being undertaken by the Government. Many of us might think that there are fatal flaws in it, but we will be able to make a considered legislative judgment only if we have full access to the facts. I make a most serious plea to the whole of the Senate that we should treat this matter in a way which accepts that we have a common purpose in there being no suppression or obscuring of whatever the facts are.

I do not intend to seek leave to continue my remarks. Perhaps I should, because if I were given leave that would block the Minister and the Australian Democrats from speaking. On the other hand, I do not wish to start a debate. It is not my wish to have a lengthy debate on this matter before the information that eventually will come through the processes of these two committees. But, from my own lengthy experience in Aboriginal affairs, it is an area where some people do play it very hard. I do not think that at the political, bureaucratic or community level anyone would deny that it is often played very hard indeed. In those circumstances there is a heavy onus on the Senate, which is the only real supervising legislative chamber in the Commonwealth-we have a peculiar responsibility-to make sure that in the hard playing which occurs in Aboriginal affairs there is not dirty playing. That is very much the determination of the Opposition at this stage.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, Senator Chaney has raised some matters for your consideration. It would not be my intention to try in any way to colour, prejudice or influence your consideration of the so-called purported question of privilege which Senator Chaney has raised for your consideration. I think there would be general agreement around this chamber that, as far as committees of this chamber and, indeed, of the other place are concerned, it is extremely important and necessary to the eventual discharge of our duties as the democratically elected representatives of the Australian people that the information, the facts and the necessary appearances take place to enable our committees to form considered judgments on the matters put to them, whether of a general policy kind, such as is being undertaken by the Senate Select Committee on the Administration of Aboriginal Affairs, or the Estimates committee which reviews the proposals for expenditure, in this case, in relation to the Department of Aboriginal Affairs and the Aboriginal Development Commission (ADC).

SPEECH.PARA: Mr Deputy President, the matter was triggered by a resolution, a copy of which was sent to Mr President after he had been questioned by Senator Boswell yesterday. He tabled that resolution just before the adjournment debate late last night. Since that time, Mr President has received a further resolution from meeting No. 63, which was obviously held this morning. Mr Deputy President, I would like to read that into the record. As I said, I read it without trying in any way to colour the position the President might eventually reach. It states:
In relation to the resolution passed at the 62nd Commission meeting concerning the presentation of papers and submissions, the Board of Commissioners wishes to inform the Senate that this resolution:
1. was not intended to in any way encroach upon or limit the powers of the Senate or any Parliamentary Committee;
2. was not intended to prevent or in any way affect the right of individuals to appear before the Senate or such committees;

3. was a purely administrative mechanism designed to ensure that papers and submissions presented on behalf of the ADC contained information that was accurate and reflected the views of the Commission;
and that the Board regrets any misunderstanding that may have occurred as a result of the passage of this resolution.

That was conveyed to Mr President over the signature of the ADC Chairman, Shirley McPherson, and the Acting Deputy Chairman, Patrick Dodson. All I wish to say in relation to that is that I have been involved with Senate committees now for some 10 years. I am sure that Senator Boswell, in his shorter time in the Senate, has been involved with Senate committees, too. Quite commonly, witnesses come before us who claim that the submission that they have put in writing or are about to make orally has been compiled on behalf of, or is about to be put on behalf of, some organisation or another. It has been my quite common experience to question such witnesses and try to ascertain whether the proper processes have been gone through by the organisation which they purport to represent. Particularly where we have national organisations of a federal character, where quite complex processes are involved in getting the final approval of the summit or peak board, one finds that the matter has not been completely processed in a way which would enable one to say that the submission is the view of that organisation as represented by its ultimate governing body. As I read the resolution of meeting No. 63 it would harmonise with that sort of approach which is, as I say, quite commonly found in the work of Senate committees. I do not doubt that Senator Boswell himself has been present on an occasion when a witness has withdrawn a document or changed the status of a document under that sort of questioning by a Senate committee. As I said, I do not want to prejudice the consideration of this matter by the President in this particular instance.

As to the appearance of witnesses before Estimates Committee E and the presentation of answers, may I say that I met with Mrs McPherson late last night. She informed me that draft answers had been prepared in response to not dozens but perhaps 200 questions put to the Commission by Senator Tambling last Friday.

TALK.START.PARA: —Last Thursday.

—Nevertheless today is only Thursday. To have those draft answers to several hundred questions compiled and ready for consideration by the board of the commissioners this morning represents a magnificent effort of will, dedication and damn hard work by the officers of the Aboriginal Development Commission. Those answers have been compiled in a way which will be helpful to the Senate Estimates Committee when it meets. I am sure that as soon as the ADC processes those responses for transmission to the Estimates Committee they will be made available-I would imagine sometime late this morning or early this afternoon. I ought to make it very clear that there is no attempt to delay or frustrate the responses to Senator Tambling's questions. Any department or agency that was confronted with that task a mere five or six days ago is to be commended if it produced those answers within that short period of time.

SPEECH.PARA: As to the appearances of witnesses before the Estimates Committee, honourable senators will understand that it is for the Minister to answer questions and to determine who shall assist. I think I took the view in answer to the first question completely without notice that the chairperson of the Aboriginal Development Commission ought to be there as the properly constituted chairperson. I took the view that the personality of the character did not matter but that the person holding the office of General Manager should be there, and that is what I said in response to Senator Boswell off the cuff. That is still my view. Other officers of the Aboriginal Development Commission can be there to assist also.

I have not finally determined a view because, to be absolutely frank with honourable senators, it is not clear from the responses which the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs (Mr Hand) has had from the ADC-and the various letters coming out of Question Time are the only knowledge that I have-what the status of certain persons within the ADC is. When that is clarified perhaps in the course of the day, we will be able to determine who shall appear at the Estimates Committee hearings. I remind honourable senators that Estimates committees are not like ordinary standing committees which can compel the attendance of persons and the presentation of documents. For Estimates committees, the Minister chooses who shall help.

TALK.START.PARA: —Do you have the responses to the letter the Minister wrote to the ADC on 14 October following Senate questions? We understand you do. They have not yet been produced. You might recall that there was a question about Mr Mick O'Brien and whether the opinion of the Attorney-General's Department had been obtained about his reported removal. The Minister wrote on 14 October. We were given copies of those letters but not of the responses. Are they available?
—The letter of 14 October was over the signature of the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs. It states:

SPEECH.PARA: Dear Mrs McPherson-
Would you please advise me of any decisions made by the ADC Commissioners in relation to the employment of Mr Mick O'Brien.

TALK.START.PARA: —I was asking about the responses to those letters.
—I am just checking that we are reading the same letters.
—Yes, we are.
—The letter goes on:

SPEECH.PARA: What position does Mr O'Brien currently hold within the Commission.
Your early response would be appreciated.
Yours sincerely
There is a response dated 14 October 1988:
Dear Minister
I attach a copy of the resolution passed by the Board of the Aboriginal Development Commission in relation to the employment of Mr Mick O'Brien.
In light of the attachment, Mr O'Brien no longer holds a position with the Commission.
Yours sincerely
S. A. McPherson

TALK.START.PARA: —Sacked.
—Senator Boswell says `sacked'. The attachment of the resolution reads as follows:

SPEECH.PARA: CREATION OF SES LEVEL 3 POSITIONS
Resolution:

In accordance with the Minister's s. 11 Direction of 27 April 1988 requiring the ADC to co-operate with the Minister and portfolio bodies in effecting the transition to ATSIC and pursuant to the Commission having set aside funds to facilitate the negotiation of a Treaty, the Commission directs that:

This position will have responsibility for liaising with the ATSIC Task Force and generally overseeing the smooth transition to ATSIC as well as responsibility for managing and controlling all aspects of the treaty consultations as well as other duties as directed.
2. the current General Manager, Mr. M. O'Brien, be placed in the above created position forthwith.

Thank you for your replies to my letters of 14 October.

With respect to the question concerning the employment of Mr O'Brien, could you explain in more detail how Mr O'Brien ``no longer holds a position within the Commission'' in the ``light of the attachment'' which says in paragraph two that ``Mr O'Brien be placed in the above created position forthwith''?
The position referred to is listed in the ADC Resolution as ``a temporary position . . . equivalent to that of an SES Level 3'', and the tasks to be undertaken are also outlined.
There has been no further response to that particular letter but I am willing to table the letters I have read if that will assist the Senate. I did not mean to go on as long as I have.

TALK.START.PARA: —The letter of even date about the legal advice was the other one I asked about.
—On 14 October 1988 a letter was sent by Mr Hand. It states:

SPEECH.PARA: Dear Mrs McPherson
I write seeking answers to questions raised in the Senate today by Senator Boswell.

Senator Boswell asked whether the ADC Board of Commissioners sought legal advice from the Attorney-General's Department in relation to the `purported removal' of Mr Mick O'Brien from the position of General Manager. Was this advice provided?
Was the Public Service Commission consulted, and did it give its approval to, the appointment of Mr Cedric Wyatt as General Manager of the ADC.
Your urgent response would be appreciated.
There was a letter of the same date from Shirley McPherson:
Dear Minister,
I refer to your letter of 14 October 1988 seeking answers to questions raised in the Senate today by Senator Boswell.
In response to the first question, the answer is No, though I understand that Acting Commissioner Perkins sought advice from Departmental officers . . .
I presume that means the Department of Aboriginal Affairs officers. I continue:
In response to the second question, the answer is No.

For completeness I have to inform honourable senators that later in the day-this letter is also dated 14 October-Mrs McPherson wrote to Mr Hand. The letter is headed M. V. O'Brien v The Aboriginal Development Commission and states:
I have today, at approximately 1 pm, received the attached letter dated 14 October, 1988, from Solicitors Manfred Stinson and Dougall who are acting for Mr O'Brien.
I have asked my Legal Branch to examine the document and the preliminary advice is that the matter should be referred as a matter of urgency to the Australian Government Solicitor.
In light of your earlier urgent requests this morning concerning Mr O'Brien I believe it is important that you are kept informed on this matter.
I am notifying all Commissioners and I will request their views on a special meeting of Commissioners for, say, Thursday 21 October 1988 to consider this matter.

The letter was meant to read `20 October 1988 to consider this matter'. No further information has been relayed by Mrs McPherson on behalf of the ADC concerning that request for legal advice. I table all the letters and correspondence dated 14 October.

TALK.START.PARA: —I appreciate the urgency of the matter of privilege that has been raised this morning by the President and the fact that he needs to seek further information and will respond further on the next day of sitting. However, the Minister for Justice (Senator Tate) has just alluded to a number of questions that I have put on notice to Senate Estimates Committee E. These questions were put on notice one week ago. The fact that they had to be put on notice and that there were several hundred of them is indicative of the seriousness of the problem that exists within both the Department of Aboriginal Affairs (DAA) and the Aboriginal Development Commission (ADC). There are three areas that I am pursuing in that line of questioning. One is the very serious matter of what, in effect, is a black mafia of corruption in the administration of Aboriginal affairs. The second is the lousy administration of the Department of Aboriginal Affairs--

—Mr Deputy President, on a point of order: I want to raise with you a question of relevance. We are debating a motion by Senator Chaney to take note of the President's statement. The issues that Senator Tambling is or may be seeking to raise in the Estimates Committee may be of great interest to him but, I contend, have no relevance to the motion before the Chair.

—I was listening to Senator Tambling with some care. I was about to warn him that he was digressing from the motion before the Chair, which is Senator Chaney's motion to take note of the President's statement. Senator Tambling should confine his remarks to that and any matters that are directly relevant to that.

—I will confine my remarks to that, Mr Deputy President. That is most appropriate. I think the fact that the answers are not yet forthcoming is a very important and urgent matter to be considered by the Senate.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy President, I present the report of the Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs entitled Feasibility of a National ID Scheme; the Tax File Number, together with submissions and transcripts of evidence.

SPEECH.PARA: Ordered that the report be printed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cooney Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the report.

This matter was originally referred to the Committee on 8 October 1987. It was supplemented on 1 June 1988 by additional terms of reference relating to the proposed tax file numbering scheme announced by the Treasurer (Mr Keating) in the 1988 May economic statement. The Committee has completed the report as expeditiously as possible in order to assist the Senate in its consideration of the Taxation Laws Amendment (Tax File Numbers) Bill, which is before the Parliament, and the Privacy Bill, which is said to be imminent. The Committee has discussed principles relevant to both pieces of legislation.

The Committee received 110 submissions. It held public hearings in Melbourne, Perth, Sydney, Brisbane and Canberra. On behalf of the Committee, I would like to thank all those people and organisations who made submissions and appeared before the Committee in public hearings. The Senate referred specific questions to the Committee, which it has answered. The answers to some are not as comprehensive as the Committee would have liked. This is because there was a paucity of evidence in respect of them. In some cases, the material was not made available-for example, the Australian Federal Police material referred to in terms of reference (d). In other cases, it apparently did not exist-for example, detailed estimates of the costs to the private sector of establishing and maintaining any national identity system.

The tax file number legislation was introduced into the House of Representatives on 1 September 1988. The Australian Taxation Office made a submission to the Committee in relation to the tax file number proposal and also appeared before the Committee. While this was of assistance to the Committee, the Committee was generally of the view that more comprehensive information and analysis would have helped it in its considerations. The Committee did not have access to the draft Privacy Bill 1988, which has been foreshadowed by both the Treasurer and the Attorney-General (Mr Lionel Bowen). The Committee understands that the draft is still subject to alterations before it is finally brought before the Parliament.

The Committee sees this report as an important contribution to the debate on both the tax file numbers Bill and the Privacy Bill 1988, when it is introduced. The Committee's principal recommendation is that appropriate privacy legislation be enacted without delay and certainly not later than the commencement of any proposed tax file number scheme. The Committee regards this as essential. The Committee recommends that the Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development Guidelines on the Protection of Privacy and Transborder Flows of Personal Data be adopted as the minimum standard for this privacy legislation.

The Committee has recommended that the privacy watchdog, which it recommended be established under privacy legislation, should, in addition to overseeing the protection of privacy, examine various matters, including the confidentiality of medical records, arrangements concerning information sharing between government agencies and the extent of data surveillance. The Committee has also recommended that the privacy watchdog consider the question of the possible regulation of the private sector by privacy legislation.

The Committee has recommended that the operation of the privacy watchdog be referred to this Committee for review after a suitable period of time. This is because the privacy legislation and the mechanisms set up under it will be unique in this country and untested. The Senate will note that this Committee fulfilled a similar and useful role in relation to the operation and administration of the freedom of information legislation.

Mr Deputy President, may I personally thank all the members of the Committee, who worked hard and expeditiously on producing this report. I understand that members of the Committee wish to speak after me, but I would like to inform the Senate that there are addendums to the report-one from Senator Alston and one from Senator Hill. I put them in that order simply because Senator Alston's name starts with an A and Senator Hill's name starts with an H and not according to the quality of the mind that was brought to the report.

TALK.START.PARA: —Not necessarily.

—No, not necessarily. I also refer to addendum No. 2, from Senator Powell. Unfortunately she has commitments elsewhere, but maybe her views will be put today by the eminent Leader of the Australian Democrats in this chamber, Senator Haines. Since I have mentioned those members of the Committee from that side of the chamber I should also mention the contribution of Senator Stone, who sits next to Senator Haines over there, and on this side, Senator Giles and Senator Collins.
