—But not separated in the sense that you are both dedicated to the cause of the Australian people, although you see that that may be benefited in different ways.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —Perhaps I should start by thanking the Chairman of the Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs and my colleagues for their work in relation to the report, and particularly Bronwyn McNaughton, the secretary of the Committee, and her staff. The task to produce this report within the time frame was not easy, particularly with the pressure put on in this place over the last few weeks in relation to the Government wishing to deal with this matter in the Parliament. I believe that the Senate will find the report useful. I remind the Senate that the Committee is unanimous in its support for the recommendations.

SPEECH.PARA: The inquiry arose from the original ID card Bill-the Australia Card, as some people refer to it. It gave the Parliament an opportunity-perhaps for the first time; certainly in recent times-to look at the whole question of the quantity of personal information that is held by governments; by which departments it is held, and the capacity for that information to be exchanged between departments, and what sorts of safeguards exist to ensure that it is not abused. Following the Australian Law Reform Commission's report it was time for the Parliament to give consideration to those particularly important matters.

We found that there is an enormous amount of personal information held by government. It was impossible, in fact, to assess adequately the quantum of that information. We indicate in our report that we believe it is something that should be pursued further, hopefully by some sort of watchdog privacy body. We accept, of course, that it is necessary for governments to have personal information. Obviously, in areas such as social security, health, and even income tax, personal information is critical for the proper functioning of government. But it is the view certainly of those of us on this side of the chamber that government should not have any more information than is absolutely necessary, and that what government can do with personal information should be strictly regulated. I think it is clear to us as a result of this inquiry-speaking for myself-that it is not adequately regulated at the moment. Thus the Committee came to the conclusion that privacy legislation is warranted.

We were a little more uncertain as to whether privacy legislation was warranted in relation to the private sector because the information is not gathered in the compulsory way that a government gains information and also because the information is not as extensive. Nevertheless, we said it is a matter that should be further pursued. We make the suggestion that a new privacy body should look into the question of whether legislation is necessary for the private sector as soon as reasonably possible.

That raises the question of privacy legislation. The Committee, of course, said that the operation of any tax file number legislation should not be commenced until there is adequate privacy legislation. That led to a difficult position for the Committee in that we all knew that there was a Bill about, but the most recent Bill produced by the Government was not before the Committee. That is regrettable. It would have been more useful to the Parliament if it had had the opportunity to discuss this Senate Committee's assessment of the Government's proposed privacy legislation. As the Minister for Justice (Senator Tate) is in the chamber, I add that I would prefer the Bill to be introduced or at least circulated so that the debate that is taking place upon it at the moment was extended to at least give other parliamentarians the opportunity to give consideration to the terms of that Bill. A copy has been provided to the shadow Attorney-General and that is useful to a limited extent, but I think all of us would like the opportunity to consider the details of that Bill and to be able to seek the advice of others and give it proper consideration. I find it a little more disturbing when we learn that some third parties outside the Parliament claim to have copies of that Bill.

TALK.START.PARA: —Not provided by me, Senator.

—I have not suggested that. I do not know who provided them. It would be helpful if parliamentarians generally were provided with copies of the draft seeing that the draft is being debated to some extent in limited circles and in some ways in wider circles. Nevertheless, this is a shortcoming of our report-that in the timeframe that has been provided and because the Bill has not been introduced or made public, it was not possible for our Committee to deal with the contents of that Bill. It was, however, possible for us to set what we think are a number of worthwhile standards for privacy legislation by which any Bill that might be introduced could be examined. That is what we sought to do.

SPEECH.PARA: That leads me to addendum one to which my name is attached. Honourable senators will note that it is not described as a dissenting report. I would put it more in terms of a qualification. There was one conclusion-it did not lead to a recommendation-which, in my assessment, did not stand up to the evidence that was put before the Committee. That related to the question as to whether it had been demonstrated that the revenue that government would gain by the proposed tax file number system would amount to a significant benefit to the revenue. I guess `significant' can only be looked at in a subjective sense, but certainly I was looking at the question as to whether there was sufficient evidence for the Committee to come to a conclusion that a substantial revenue advantage would be obtained as a result of the introduction of the new scheme. It was my conclusion that on the evidence-and the principal evidence was that of the Australian Taxation Office-that case had not been made out. I went on to say in the addendum, and I think it was important to say, that I believe before a tax file number system is introduced there is an onus on government and the proponents of such a scheme to show that there are not less intrusive methods that could be used to achieve a similar result. In the evidence that was put before the Committee I certainly was not convinced that there were no other less intrusive methods that could, in fact, achieve a similar result.

Very briefly, in explaining what I have just said, we know that the Australian Taxation Office very effectively in recent years has been building a matching capacity-to match sources of revenue to taxpayers. In fact, we were told in evidence that there are now approximately 12 million entries that are matched each year. This has been successful and has resulted in an ever increasing number of assessments being amended with an ever increasing revenue benefit in tax and penalties. I set that out on page 2 of addendum 1, the information being taken from the Taxation Office's evidence. We find with the existing system that in the year 1987-88 some $139m had been produced through the Taxation Office's matching capacity. It is important to realise that that matching capacity is proving effective because of the very extensive powers that the Parliament has already given to the Taxation Office to make such a facility operative. I set out those further powers on page 2 of the addendum. We have now provided an obligation on employers to report details of salaries and wages paid, on companies to report details of all interest payments made in excess of $100, on companies to report to the Australian Taxation Office details of all dividend payments made, and on payers of payments made subject to the prescribed payment system to report details of payments made. So it could be said that we have already gone down the path of intrusive type legislation a great deal. As I said, that has given the Australian Taxation Office the significant capacity to match sources of income with taxpayers. That would seem to be being done reasonably effectively, accepting that there is room for the existing system to be be extended yet further.

The Government's preference is to introduce a new methodology, a taxation file number system, that will oblige taxpayers to provide a unique identifier, their tax number, when carrying out a whole series of private commercial transactions, whether it be in relation to their banking, the purchase of shares or financial transactions of that nature. I say in this addendum that, firstly, I do not believe that the evidence that has been put before us warrants that intrusion and, secondly, the Government has not exhausted the alternatives of further development of the existing scheme, short of this further legislative intrusion.

Very briefly, if we look at the sums that the Australian Taxation Office says will be produced by this unique identifier method, I do not believe that they stand critical analysis. The two principal parts were basically from group certificates that are not lodged and from interest that is not declared. In relation to the group certificates, as I recall the evidence the calculation was made from a very small sample of 500 and, of the 500, only 100 could not be traced. But when we examined those that could be traced further we saw that 65 per cent of them represented group certificates that would actually result in the taxpayer getting a refund. Those refunds were not quantified in the evidence that was put before the Committee; therefore, it is impossible for us to come to a net figure. The figure given by the Taxation Office was not a net figure; it was a gross figure.

Certainly, it was said in evidence that the refunds are likely to be smaller sums of money than those when tax is payable. But, of course, large sums of money are independently investigated by the Taxation Office, as is the case at present. I was not left in a position where I could be confident that, when the figure was netted out, it would come anywhere near the sum that was claimed by the Australian Taxation Office in its evidence. Furthermore, as we know, the recent amnesty has resulted in a large number of new taxpayers being brought into the system and the effect of that was also not taken into account and I suggest that that will reduce the opportunity to gain funds through a tax file number system.

With regard to the other half of the equation-the interest that is not currently declared-again there was no significant scientific reason to reach the figure that was claimed by the Australian Taxation Office. It resulted from a survey that was done in 1983-84, a very long time ago, before the Tax Office commenced to develop the sophisticated matching arrangement that it presently has and, in addition, it was as a result of what the Tax Office has described as `a feel for the matter'. It is my view that those who are proponents of the scheme who seek to justify these figures need to produce better evidence than that to the Parliament. We must accept that, even in the way the Government intends to structure this new scheme, a very large number of taxpayers will not be included-pensioners and children under 16-and that amounts to some millions of bank accounts that are unlikely to be included. So there has to be a major flaw in the matching capacity. I would have thought that anyone would accept that point. When we finally got to the bottom line it was interesting to find that, in the opinion of the Department, if the new scheme was introduced, 70 per cent of the interest might still be avoided. So it is far from a foolproof scheme.

We have to weigh the intrusions against the benefits. In my respectful submission, as I have said in this addendum, that did not match up. As I said in the final part of the addendum, I would much prefer the Government to be looking at the alternatives to bring partnerships, trusts and companies within the current matching system which would bring in another one million business taxpayers and significantly improve the matching capacity. I believe that the Government could look further at using payee account numbers, something which was dismissed somewhat superficially by the Taxation Office in its evidence. To me that is a less intrusive method which will produce the same results. In summary, that is a qualification to one of the conclusions but the recommendations are unanimous.

Finally, let me simply stress that we, on this side of the chamber, are not seeking in this addendum not to reduce tax avoidance. We are looking at a more effective scheme so that there will be less tax avoidance. But we say that, in developing that scheme, the losses of personal privacy and unnecessary intrusions must always be weighed against the advantages to be gained. Every effort must be made in framing legislation to avoid unnecessary intrusions. As I have stated in the addendum, I believe that there are more effective, less intrusive ways of achieving the same goal.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collins Sen R.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —As Senator Hill said quite correctly, this report of the Senate Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs was prepared under a great deal of pressure. However, the report is a carefully considered one and I am afraid that, as usual, the pressure was mostly borne by the staff of the Committee. They worked very long hours on this report and, as the final additions to it were not even in the hands of the staff until the middle of yesterday afternoon, I think they have performed a commendable job in having this report, in its completed form, tabled in the chamber this morning. I would like to commend Kathleen Gibson, Barry Jenkins-I will not ask them to stand up and take a bow-Stephen Argument and Bronwyn McNaughton for the enormous amount of work and the very fine drafting job that they have done.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Alston and Senator Hill have done the Opposition's case on the tax file number a great deal of damage. In fact, it would have been much safer for Senator Alston and Senator Hill not to have made this addendum to the report because not only have they made fools of themselves but also they have made fools of the Opposition. A number of cynics, perhaps on this side of the House and maybe in the community at large, feel that the Opposition's concern about privacy matters-I stress that its concern has rested on privacy matters-is not genuine but is simply a sham and a fraud in attempting to delay and defer, once again, the Government's opportunity to introduce this proposal to crack down on tax cheats. Of course, the Opposition is sensitive to the fact that, because of its previous full-blooded support for the upgraded tax file number-which I will move to shortly-it cannot now simply capriciously reject it; it has to search around for some reason to do it.

I am still prepared to give the Opposition the benefit of the doubt as to its concern about privacy issues. The Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard) has stated very clearly that it is predicated on the Opposition's satisfaction with the details of the privacy legislation, that the Opposition's support for, or rejection of, the tax file number will be based on that. I am prepared to give the Opposition the benefit of the doubt. But do we find any mention of concerns about privacy? In Senator Alston's and Senator Hill's addendum to this report we do not. For the first time that I am aware of in the debate we have a complete switch-I will quote from the addendum itself-on where the Opposition now lies.

From the evidence that was given to this Committee and from the record of the Australian Taxation Office (ATO) in providing estimates-which I will get to shortly-I would have thought that we could have opposed the upgraded tax file number on a great many grounds, but not that one. Before I get to the addendum I will canvass a number of key paragraphs in the report itself and I will be brief because of time constraints. Paragraph 2.21 of the report, quoting a term of reference, says that the Committee had to inquire into:

the taxation file numbering scheme announced by the Treasurer in the May Economic Statement, and, in particular, whether the scheme is likely to improve the efficiency of the taxation system and to eliminate fraud and abuses in the taxation and social security systems.
The Committee concluded in the next paragraph:
. . . the tax file numbering scheme proposed by the Treasurer is likely to improve the efficiency of the taxation system and to assist in the elimination of fraud and abuse of that system.
I highlight paragraph 9.39 of the report because this is the paragraph that Senator Hill and Senator Alston have some difficulty with. The majority of the Committee said:
The tax file number scheme is likely to result in a substantial overall gain in revenue by eliminating certain areas of fraudulent practice in, and abuse of, the taxation system.

The report goes on to say that there are other areas-as Senator Hill quite rightly said-of abuse that the enhanced tax file number scheme will not address. I turn to Senator Hill's and Senator Alston's addendum. It says this:

On the evidence put to the Committee we are not satisfied that the tax file number would result in a significant increase in revenue. We therefore disagree with the view of the majority of the Committee on this point.
It then goes on to say, and these are the two grounds on which this position is based:

On the evidence put to the Committee we are not satisfied that other less intrusive methods do not exist. Indeed, we express disappointment at the cursory manner in which alternative approaches were treated in the ATO submission.
So the position of the Opposition in the Senate in respect of this matter--

TALK.START.PARA: —It is not the position of the Opposition.

—I am sorry. I apologise. The position of Senator Alston and Senator Hill on this matter is that they are not satisfied to support the tax file number on the grounds, first, that they dispute the assessment of the Taxation Office that there will be significant gains in revenue and, second, that there are other less intrusive methods of raising revenue. On the question of whether the Committee could fairly be expected to accept the evidence of the Taxation Office on the question of revenue raising I just say this: I, along with other members of the Committee, had some dissatisfaction with the manner in which the Taxation Office presented some of its case and those concerns are reflected-I might add-in paragraphs 9.26 and 9.30 of the report. But I had no difficulty whatsoever in accepting the estimates the Taxation Office provided on the significant revenue to be gained from the implementation of this measure. The reason I made that assessment on the evidence is this, and I quote from the submission given to the Committee by the Australian Taxation Office:

SPEECH.PARA: Calculation of the tax file number revenue estimates followed a similar methodology to that used in calculating the Australia Card revenue estimates, with reductions to reflect the narrower uses and lower integrity of the tax file number proposals.

There is a reference, and I have the full reference with me, in the report of the Joint Select Committee on an Australia Card, but it is quoted here, that the majority report-in fact I think it was unanimous on this point-of the Joint Select all-party Committee on an Australia Card said at paragraph 1.42:
The Committee accepts estimates made by the Australian Taxation Office and notes that they may be a substantial underestimation of final benefits obtainable under the proposal.

TALK.START.PARA: —Underestimation?

—Underestimation. It is also fair, I think, to have a look at the Taxation Office's record in providing estimates to committees of all kinds of this Parliament and Budget estimates and at what sort of consistent record it has achieved in providing such estimates. I would like to note in respect of this the comment of the Commonwealth Auditor-General in the 1986 efficiency audit of the Australian Taxation Office where he said that the key assumptions underlying the revenue estimates by the Taxation Office may be conservative. I in fact have a copy of the 1986 efficiency audit with me. It is a comprehensive document and it would take me too long to quote from it fully, but that is a fair summary of what the Commonwealth Auditor-General said about the estimates of the Taxation Office.

SPEECH.PARA: Now, does the Commonwealth Auditor-General, and do I, have reasonable grounds for believing that the Taxation Office has a consistent record of conservatism and care in underestimating estimates? Yes, he does and I do. Again, without being exhaustive about it-and I can assure Senator Hill and Senator Alston, and the Senate, that I could quote considerably more than I am about to here-but just going to the immediate past, I would like the Senate to consider the estimates that were provided by the Taxation Office on a number of Budget measures in the 1987-88 financial year compared with the actual revenue received. I only have to go back one year.

The Taxation Office estimated that in that financial year $530m would be received from the fringe benefits tax. The actual figure was $881m. On capital gains tax the Taxation Office estimated that we would receive $5m from that measure. The actual figure received was $400m. In the area of entertainment, the estimate from the Taxation Office was that $330m would be achieved from that measure. The actual figure was in fact $330m. On substantiation requirements, the estimate from the Australian Taxation Office was that $105m would be received. The actual receipts were $350m. I would also point out-and I could go on and on-that the company tax collections in 1987-88 were $1.1 billion higher than the Taxation Office estimates. There is a reason for that. It is that the professional officers who work for the Australian Taxation Office do tend to be ultra-conservative, for obvious reasons, and careful in the estimates that they provide on revenue. There is a fairly commonsense reason for that.

No-one is going to pillory the Tax Office or the officers concerned if they say, `We are going to collect $100m' and we collect $300m. No-one is going to pillory the Taxation Office if $1.1 billion is collected in addition to their estimates. No-one is going to pillory the Taxation Office if $881m is collected instead of $530m. But, of course, a great deal would be said if there were substantial over-estimates. The fact is, and the Committee was in a position to consider this because we had all of this evidence I am quoting now before us, that the Taxation Office has an impeccable record, acknowledged by the Commonwealth Auditor-General, of consistently being conservative in the estimates provided to committees or to the Treasurer or wherever else.

Therefore I think the Committee was entitled, despite any minor complaints reflected in our report with the presentation made by the Taxation Office, on the record and on the facts before us, to accept the estimates of the Australian Taxation Office as a conservative estimate of what might be collected by this Budget measure. Those estimates, for the benefit of the Senate, are that there will be a gross increase in collections over a 10-year period of $2.2 billion, with an estimated cost of collecting those revenues of less than $300m, giving a ratio of $8.07 collected for every dollar expended in that collection. Frankly, I do not know how one can ignore submissions such as that. The Australian Taxation Office has a very good record in two areas. It has a very good record in the impeccable way it preserves the confidentiality of its records, and it has a very good record of consistently providing conservative estimates of its revenue collections.

I would now like to turn to the brilliant solution that Senators Hill and Alston provide as an alternative to the tax file number. They say that they are extremely disappointed that we did not do enough work on that and that, indeed, the Tax Office did not provide better alternatives. What would they do? I turn to page 124 of the report, and here it is:
The first alternative is to further develop the existing matching facility without the intrusion of a new obligatory tax file number identification.
There are only three paragraphs here. The next one canvasses the question of payee account numbers. The third paragraph refers back to the first paragraph. The final paragraph states:
Certainly without first exhausting the capacities of the existing matching facility further legislative intrusions on personal privacy are unwarranted.

So the only solution offered as an alternative by Senators Hill and Alston is an improvement in the existing matching facilities. I think it is fair to have a look at what the Taxation Office said about this. I refer the Senate to the submission given to this Committee by the ATO. Again I cannot, in the time available to me, be exhaustive about this, so I will have to provide a summary. I think it is a compelling summary to anyone who understands even the basics of computer systems and databases. This is what the ATO said in paragraph 2.8 of its submission:

It is in recognition of these factors and concern for the level of evasion that the ATO has been expanding its income matching activities in recent years, primarily in the area of interest reporting and matching. That expansion is reflected in the results that have been achieved, measured in terms of assessments amended and the resultant tax and penalties raised.
This is the very measure that Senator Hill is providing as the only alternative to the upgraded tax file number. It goes on in paragraph 2.9 to say:

Despite the progress that has been made, the conduct of the Income Matching Program is considerably labour intensive, much of this being due to the system of name and address matching on which it is based.
I should have thought that that was one of those truths we hold to be self-evident. It goes on:
Furthermore, program results fall well short of realising their full potential, for the following reasons:

Because of the difficulties experienced in computer based name and address matching for individuals (refer para 3.4 et seq.), no attempts have been made to date to devise a systems-based matching facility in respect of partnership, trust and company taxpayers (refer para 3.9 et seq.). Thus, a very large number of business taxpayers-in excess of 1 million-who derive interest income are excluded from the interest reporting and matching element of the Income Matching Program.

Senator Hill and Senator Alston must have been asleep when the ATO was presenting the Committee with that evidence. I find it compelling evidence not just in terms of being prepared to accept the professional assessment of taxation officers, but purely in terms of a commonsense assessment of the clumsiness and expense of a system that relies on names and addresses rather than a system that simply relies on matching two identical numbers. As I said when I opened this contribution, I do not think Senators Hill and Alston have helped themselves in terms of their own credibility, and certainly the credibility of the Opposition, on this issue. But then we get to the most astonishing part of this addendum, where Senators Hill and Alston say:

Yet even with the enhanced tax file number system a large number of income sources will not be matched because pensioners (2.5 million) and children (4 million) are excluded. It is suspected that the largest potential revenue is from small income earners as large unaccounted income is already presently investigated.

I will not tell the Senate what I have written across that particular paragraph. The only interpretation that can be placed on that paragraph is that Senators Hill and Alston are not satisfied with the upgraded tax file number because it does not go far enough in including `small income earners' in the collection of revenue. I have no hesitation in saying comprehensively and categorically that the Government has not the slightest intention of introducing the Hill/Alston upgraded tax file number and coming down on 2.5 million Australian pensioners and four million children that the Government has excluded from the provisions of the Bill. The Government has no intention of following the Hill/Alston upgraded tax file number plan, but I must say that, with respect to the current position of the Opposition, I would describe this contribution or this addendum as perverse.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Liberals.
—Of the Liberals, I am sorry. It is the only description one can put on it. It is internally contradictory; in fact, `perverse' is not too strong a word. The report then goes on:

SPEECH.PARA: Even with the tax file number scheme the ATO estimates that 70% of interest upon which tax is not paid could still be avoided. It will be far from a foolproof system.

Once again, in stating the obvious, I have to agree with that conclusion. Is Senator Hill once again saying-and I assume he is-by necessary inference that he will agree with the tax file number only when it covers that section that is excluded? The reality, of course, is that it is the only commonsense interpretation of the references to this paragraph and certainly the unmistakable reference to pensioners and children.

TALK.START.PARA: —It's simply showing that your matching system is full of holes.
—Well, we will go back again:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . even with the enhanced tax file number system, a large number of income sources will not be matched because pensioners (2.5 million) and children (4 million) are excluded.
There is enough inference in the first sentence but it is unmistakable in the second. I will quote the second sentence:
It is suspected that the largest potential revenue is from small income earners . . .

That includes the pensioners and children that Senators Hill and Alston have just mentioned. Of course, there is a large potential tax source in those 2.5 million pensioners and four million children but the Government has no intention of collecting it. It is, as I said, a fairly perverse contribution to this debate.

Let us look at what the Opposition has said previously about the upgraded tax file number. I refer to the report of the Joint Select Committee on an Australia Card. I am quoting from the majority report, with the only dissent, let me remind honourable senators, being from Labor Party members-yes, Senator Haines-of this Committee. Let me quote what the majority report, the Opposition's report, said. Paragraph 1.42 states:

The Committee is unanimous in its view that tax evasion must be tackled as vigorously as possible. While it does have strong doubts that the so-called black economy, especially the cash economy, can be tackled by any one measure including the Australia Card proposal, it believes that every effort must be made to reduce tax evasion. Overall, the Committee accepts the estimates made by the Australian Taxation Office and notes that they may be a substantial underestimation of final benefits obtainable under the proposal.

Once again, that is evidence-agreed to by the Opposition-of the practice of the ATO to be conservative in its estimates, a position now being rejected by Senator Hill and Senator Alston. It goes on in paragraph 4.19-and this was the then position of the Opposition-to say:
4.19 The majority of the Committee considers as an appropriate option the upgrading of the tax file number to a level of integrity equivalent to that of the Australia Card number . . .

I repeat that: `upgrading to the equivalent of the Australia Card number'. In other words, not so long ago the Opposition was perfectly happy to insist on a level of integrity of the upgraded tax file number greater than that now currently proposed by the Government. The report goes on to say:

The Committee also considers the legislation enacted to require financial institutions to use the tax file number should include a requirement that the information reported to the ATO be provided in an acceptable format.

Finally, I want to turn to the special addendum to the report of the Joint Select Committee on an Australia Card, put by Senator Puplick, the Senate's Opposition representative on this Committee. The addendum section is headed `There is a better way'. This is what Senator Puplick says:

The majority of the members of the Joint Select Committee share many of my concerns about the Australia Card proposal. As a result they have decided on balance to recommend against adoption of the Government's proposal in its present form.
The second sentence is the important one. It says:
However, we realise that this casts upon us-
that is, the Opposition-
a clear responsibility to recommend some alternative which addresses at least the area of particular concern, namely tax evasion.

What was the alternative that the Opposition-and indeed the Senate Opposition-seized upon? It was this:

The Report of the Joint Select Committee thus proposes as its central recommendation the use of an improved and upgraded system based upon a tax file number of higher integrity than that currently used. SPEECH.SPEAKER: Haines Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I, for one, accept the estimates of the Treasurer (Mr Keating) of revenue to be raised should this legislation pass through the Senate. However, I question that this method is the only method by which this money could be raised. While we are talking about revenue, let us put it in perspective. In introducing this legislation, the Treasurer mentioned a figure of $2 billion over a 10-year period-that is $200m a year, or 26c per week per person in this country.
—Cheaper than the ABC.

—I am not sure about that; but I certainly agree that we could fund the Australian Broadcasting Corporation a whole lot better on that. We are talking about implementing a potentially intrusive piece of legislation in order to gain 26c per week per person, when there are other methods that are less intrusive that would raise the same amount of money. I do not want to sound peevish in questioning the Government's integrity in claiming that this is the only means whereby it could raise 26c per person per week. Far be it from me to be peevish. However, I remind honourable senators, and the one journalist who has sufficient interest in this matter to be in the gallery, that in 1985 the Government told us that the only way to recoup the $1 billion that it claimed was lost annually through tax and social security cheating was to introduce a national identification system.
—You remember that, do you?

—Yes, I certainly do; I remember it vividly. Yet, between 1985 and the end of 1987 the Government put into practice a large number of measures which raised $800m of that $1,000m annually. I made a speech on 7 October 1987 and, if Senator Aulich or anyone else wants to look at the various measures that the Government put into place, both through legislation and through administrative decisions, he can go back and have a look at that list. SPEECH.PARA: Senator Collins is perfectly correct in saying that the report from the Joint Select Committee on an Australia Card talked about using an upgraded, high integrity tax file number-provided that this was done in an acceptable format. This is not an acceptable format and neither was the Australia Card.

I have seen press reports in the Age, for example, as recently as yesterday which claim that the Liberal Party of Australia-and I presume that they include the National Party of Australia in that description-and the Australian Democrats are opposing this legislation because we support tax cheats and social security defrauders. Claude Forell, who wrote the article, listed his tax file number at the top of it and said that he did not care who knew his number.

TALK.START.PARA: —Neither do I.

—Well, I do not particularly care who knows Senator Collins's number or my number either, but that is not the point at issue. Mr Forell claimed that anybody who opposed this legislation had something to hide or was prepared to hide something for other people. Let me say categorically that neither I nor any of my colleagues in the Australian Democrats support tax cheats or social security defrauders. However, I do question the Government's sincerity about recouping revenue when it has inserted in various pieces of tax law measures that allow some companies in this country to legally pay less than one cent in the dollar in tax year after year after year. When the Government comes to terms with that, I will accept that it is far more sincere in its attitude to raising revenue than it has demonstrated to date.

SPEECH.PARA: The Democrats are not opposed to Government attempts to catch the cheats or people defrauding the system. Our record on supporting the Government on legislation such as the prescribed payments scheme to crack down on the cash economy is evidence of this. Furthermore, we have argued for years that the Government and the Australian Taxation Office (ATO) have to improve the integrity of the tax file number. For heaven's sake, it does not even have the integrity of the passport system we have in this country.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It being 12.45 p.m., under sessional order I should suspend the sitting of the Senate for lunch. Is it the wish of the Senate that the sitting should continue? Is there any dissenting voice? There being no dissenting voice, it is so ordered. I call Senator Haines.

—To this stage there has not been any requirement for anybody in receipt of a tax file number to prove that he is who he says he is. That has been the source of massive problems, with individuals having several tax file numbers in several different names. I noticed in one of the newspapers this week that the Tax Office had the unmitigated gall to complain about the fact that it could only locate these people accidentally, if they were silly enough to list the same address for each of their false names. The ATO has a perfectly acceptable remedy for this. It could take exactly the same measure as is taken with regard to passports-that is, to require proof of identity.

SPEECH.PARA: What the Democrats have been opposed to, and what they will continue to be opposed to, is any attempt by any government to impose a national identification card system on this country or any system that would facilitate its introduction. To help the Government in its revenue-raising capacity, to help it collect this outstanding $200m per year, most of which emanated from a failure by people to report interest earned on bank or building society accounts or in other interest bearing areas, I went to the Government late in 1987 with an alternative proposal which would have used the tax file number but which would have retained the current system, whereby the tax file number is known only to the Australian Tax Office and to the holder of the number. It would have raised the revenue but it would not have laid the groundwork for a future national identification system.

Senator Powell, in her addendum to the report by the Senate Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs-and, like Senator Hill, I want it to be noted that it is not a dissenting report from the majority report; it is simply an addendum-points out that any numbering system designed to eliminate fraud and abuse in the taxation system must accomplish two things. Firstly, it must operate efficiently to catch tax evaders. Until we improve the integrity of tax file numbers there will not be a great deal of efficiency in the system. Secondly, it must provide adequate protection against invasion of privacy. Senator Powell points out in paragraph 3 that the current system proposed by the Government has enormous potential for the invasion of people's privacy. She then goes on to give-as, I understand it, other people have not-an alternative, based on the scheme that I talked about to senior officers in the Department of the Treasury 12 months ago. It is a simple, efficient system involving a scheme similar to group certificates, and not difficult to comprehend. So, for example, with regard to bank accounts, a customer would go into a branch, give her name, get the account details and her name entered on a form that would be in quadruplicate. And let us not fancy that we do not have this system. Senator Collins is screwing up his nose. What the heck does he think group certificates are?

TALK.START.PARA: —It is very expensive to do it that way.

—So the Government is going to withdraw group certificates? They are also expensive. Come on! We want a consistent, similar system in this country, one that will recoup the revenue and not distort the arrangement that has existed in this country for decades between the ATO and the individual. I might add that Senator Aulich's concern was not shared by these officers.
—It is very expensive.

—It is also workable, and it preserves two factors that need to be preserved-efficiency and protection. It means that the bank does not have the tax file number, but the recipient and the Tax Office do. I will not go into the details; they are in the addendum. As Senator Powell points out in paragraph 5, the system we are proposing is similar to the system of group certificates. It is more than appropriate. It is not too late for the Government to rethink this issue and restructure its system along those lines. I doubt whether there would be an individual in this place who would oppose something similar to it.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Powell's addendum also deals with the question of privacy, pointing out-it is a very valuable paragraph-that the minimum requirements for privacy legislation are that it must be based on comprehensive, plainly expressed guidelines. She suggests that the Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development guidelines would be appropriate, that the private sector must be regulated, that enforceable remedies must be available and that a watchdog or privacy commissioner must be established and vested with adequate powers and independence. Finally, an appeals mechanism must exist.

The ball is definitely in the Government's court. The Government has the capacity to recoup the 26c per person per week loss in revenue, and without infringing the confidentiality provisions currently existing between the Tax Office and the individual. It can do so without either risking an Australia Card rerun or infringing people's privacy.

TALK.START.PARA: —I feel compelled to address the Senate on some of the issues raised by speakers on the other side, in particular the Australian Democrats. This Government is, undoubtedly, sincere in its desire to pursue tax reform. No government in the last 40 years has done it so zealously or with such consistency. At the time Senator Haines, as a member of that Committee, said, `Yes, the Democrats are keen to stamp out tax evasion'. Tax evasion was rampant in the community. Everyone, right down to John Howard, believed that that was the case.

SPEECH.PARA: The big question was how we were to stamp out tax evasion. We brought in the Australia Card proposal. What did the Democrats do? We do not mind holding the baby because we believe that tax evasion should be stamped out.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is a wonderfully mixed metaphor.

—Aside from mixing metaphors, the options are these: there was the Australia Card system. We could not get an Australia Card system because the Democrats would not support us in this chamber. There is a tax file number system proposed, the option proposed to us by the Joint Select Committee. Now we have problems with that. Why? Because Senator Haines opposes it.
—Mr Deputy President, I take a point of order. I think Senator Aulich was, like I was once, a teacher. He knows the difference between `upgraded' and `extended'.
—Order! State your point of order, Senator Haines.
—Mr Deputy President, I would like you to insist on accuracy from the honourable senator opposite.
—That is not a prerogative of the Chair in this chamber.

—It is true; I was a teacher, and I have not stopped fulfilling that role. I am teaching Senator Haines now about the facts of life. I have described the options. The Australia Card was thrown out because the Democrats did not want it. Having put the tax file number system as a proposal, the Democrats now say that they do not want that, either. So where do we go from there? The options are simple. We can go back to an old fashioned approach of the Australian Taxation Office. We can say to the Taxation Office, `You have a problem in this country of tax evasion and minimisation that is damaging the political fabric of our society. You go out and stop it'. So what does the Australian Tax Office do? It uses sections 263 and 264 of the tax Act-powers it has now-which give it untrammelled rights as a government organisation to go into offices and private homes to check records without a warrant and pursue people in a way that, if it did it vigorously, would abuse all the civil rights that Senator Haines believes are so important.

SPEECH.PARA: There are a number of people in both the private and companies areas who are concerned about the way the Tax Office is working. They are concerned because I suppose they are the recipients of the zealousness of the Tax Office. But some of us on this side are concerned that the Tax Office has to use those powers in order to get the revenue that at the moment is being evaded by various groups in the community, particularly those associated with companies.

May I just mention another point that Senator Haines mentioned. If we really want to get back revenue that is evaded through tax minimisation or genuine evasion in the companies area then we ought to go to those companies and do something about that. I can assure Senator Haines that one of the views that I have long held is that if we really want to stop tax evasion in this country then we have to look at the $2 companies. We should, as a Commonwealth government, go to State governments and say, `Do you want to reform taxation in this country? Do you want to make sure that companies act according to the appropriate way? Then you come to us and we will talk about reforming company codes in this country'. We cannot stop tax evasion until we look at the company codes and the plethora of $2 companies that exist in this society and the ways in which at this stage particularly tax accountants are advising their clients to operate.

There are two fronts if we are really going to stamp out tax evasion. We have to have an Australia Card. If we do not have that we must have a tax file number of great integrity with the appropriate civil liberties protections. We also need to reform the company codes in the various States through cooperation with the Commonwealth Government. The Government is moving in that direction. We want the Democrats' support. We do not want them to go weak at the knees when we bring into this chamber legislation that has had a great deal of thought and time given to it. I looked at that report. SPEECH.SPEAKER: Stone Sen J.O.

TALKER.NAME: Senator STONE
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —Normally when a report of a standing committee of the Senate is tabled in this place and it is a committee of which I am a member I do not seek to speak on the initial tabling motion. But I have been forced to speak today because I fear very much that there is some possibility, in the light of developments very late in the preparation of this report-Feasibility of a National ID Scheme; the Tax File Number-that the debate on it could be distorted. I am reinforced in that view by the remarks earlier today by my colleague on this side of the chamber Senator Hill, who in speaking particularly to his addendum to the report made a number of statements which, I have to say, I disagree with.

SPEECH.PARA: It is very important when a Senate standing committee has spent a long time producing a report on an important topic and has presented it to the Senate that the debate arising out of that report should start off on the right foot. It is therefore very clear that we need to get a few facts straight about the matters covered in the report and in the course of the debate earlier today.

The first point I want to make in that connection is to note that this report arose out of the reference to the Senate Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs as long ago as 8 October last year immediately following the defeat of the Australia Card proposal.

It was only on 1 June this year, eight months later, that a further reference was given to the Senate Committee arising out of the announcement by the Treasurer (Mr Keating) that he proposed to introduce a tax file numbering system. In the last few weeks, as it became known that the Senate Committee was approaching the end of its labours, and in particular as the tax file number legislation made its way into and partly through the Parliament, public interest, and particularly the interest of the media, intensified. I suggest that the interest related not so much to the original reference to this Committee but to the addendum to that reference, namely, those parts of the reference which deal with the tax file number.

I think it is very important, therefore, that we keep the nature of this report in perspective. The report is not principally about the tax file number, although one would be hard put, in the light of the discussion arising out of the tabling this morning, to have drawn that conclusion. The report is principally about the original reference to the Committee and in particular about the questions of privacy to which that reference was principally directed. It is true that the report also covers, in its final two chapters, the tax file number reference. It does so in a very specific manner-a manner specifically directed to its terms of reference rather than to the more generalised concerns that have been raised in many quarters, I think with justice, about the proposal for a tax file number itself.

The Committee's terms of reference have led, therefore, to 16 recommendations. Fifteen of those recommendations deal with the question of privacy and the last of them only deals with the question of the tax file number. I want very briefly to take those points in turn. I do not want to spend time now addressing the recommendations which deal with privacy-the first 15-as they have been touched upon particularly by Senator Hill, if I recall correctly, and by other speakers. I say in passing that, while I agree with much of what Senator Collins said in his earlier remarks, I have to reject his unwarranted imputation that the concern that has been expressed in this report and elsewhere by Opposition senators and by the Opposition more generally about the question of privacy might be thought to spring from a desire-I am not quoting Senator Collins precisely but I do not think I am misrepresenting him-to rationalise the Opposition's prospective opposition to the tax file number.

TALK.START.PARA: —I said I was prepared to give you the benefit of the doubt.

—Senator Collins, as he now reminds me, did say that he was prepared to give the Opposition the benefit of the doubt. I acknowledge his subsequent correction, but I want to put it on the record that I thought his remarks in that respect were less persuasive than some other aspects of his remarks earlier today.

SPEECH.PARA: I want to look, however, at recommendation 16, the only recommendation which deals with the Taxation Laws Amendment (Tax File Numbers) Bill 1988. I emphasise in particular that what that recommendation says-namely, that the Bill should be strictly limited in its terms, and so on-is specifically qualified by the words `if enacted'. It was by definition the unanimous view of the Committee that that recommendation in no way committed any member of the Committee to a view that the tax file number proposal should be enacted. In the final outcome members on the Government side would no doubt have a different view of that from that which members on this side might have, but I underline the importance of those two words, `if enacted'. Having made that comment, I also want to emphasise, as I think has been said by others, that the whole 16 recommendations in this report are unanimously supported by all members of the Committee.

It is true that, as distinct from the formal recommendations contained in the report, the Committee in the course of its deliberations also arrived at some findings, or conclusions, as I think Senator Hill referred to them. I want to mention a very few of those findings in respect of those parts of the report which deal with the privacy questions and that part of the report which deals with the tax file number. In paragraph 9.25 of the report the Committee deals with the tax file number. This finding played a significant part in the discussion this morning. It says:

It seemed clear on the evidence before the Committee that the introduction of the proposed tax file number scheme would be likely to improve the efficiency of the taxation system and assist in eliminating some aspects of fraud and abuse in that system.

In choosing those words the Committee was responding specifically to term of reference (a), one of the two additional terms of reference provided to the Committee by this Senate on 1 June 1988. In paragraph 9.26 of its report the Committee, after briefly surveying the evidence that had been presented to it in relation to the revenue estimates, concluded:
Nevertheless, despite the deficiencies-
that is, some deficiencies in that evidence-
the Committee accepted that the introduction of the tax file number would result in a significant increase in revenue.

That conclusion has been qualified by Senators Hill and Alston in addendum 1 to the Committee's report. I was glad to hear Senator Hill say this morning that this addendum constitutes not a dissent but a qualification. The qualification boils down to saying that my two Opposition colleagues did not find the evidence presented to the Committee, particularly by the Australian Taxation Office, sufficiently compelling to enable them to concur in the view, which I quoted a moment ago, in paragraph 9.26 of the report.

The Committee carefully surveyed the Australian Taxation Office evidence and the results of its deliberations upon that evidence are contained in paragraphs 9.27 to 9.38 inclusive of its report. In those paragraphs the Committee notes a number of deficiencies which emerged in the course of our examination of the officers from the Taxation Office who appeared before us-an examination in which it is fair to say, as I think the Chairman would acknowledge, that I played a not inconsiderable part. But the bottom line to those paragraphs is that, after having considered the deficiencies in the evidence, the majority of the Committee, including me, concluded that there was no reasonable conclusion other than to agree with the statement in paragraph 9.26; namely that, despite these deficiencies, the Committee accepted that the introduction of the tax file number would result in a significant increase in revenue. I personally regret that, at a very late stage in the Committee's deliberations, my two colleagues on the Opposition side found it impossible finally to concur in that conclusion and felt it necessary to qualify the report in that respect.

Since addendum one played a prominent part in the discussion of the Committee's report this morning, and will no doubt continue to do so in the subsequent public debate, I have to say that I think two aspects of that addendum, properly considered, go beyond the ambit of the report. I wish in no way to take fine points concerning the terms of reference or anything of that kind but, in addressing the question of possible alternatives to the tax file number, my colleagues have not confined themselves to the terms of reference of the Committee, which did not provide for an examination of alternatives. As a matter of fact, the Committee had a discussion of that subject at one point of its deliberations, although Senator Hill may not have been present at that time. We concluded, after examination, that there was no provision which would allow us to examine the question of alternatives-and so we did not.

I come to the second point at which the addendum goes beyond the terms of reference or, rather, falls into what I would have to describe as irrelevance. In paragraphs 12 and 13 it refers first to the question of the exclusion from the proposed tax file number system of pensioners and children and, secondly, to the fact-admitted by the Taxation Office-that, if introduced, the tax file number system would not pick up more than about 30 per cent of interest currently untaxed. Both of those are statements of fact, but they are quite irrelevant to whether or not the Taxation Office's estimate of net revenue gain from the introduction of a tax file number system is justified, which I took to be the matter to which addendum 1 is directed. I simply place those points on the record.
The bottom line to this aspect of the Committee's findings, as has been mentioned by an earlier speaker, is in paragraph 9.38 of the report, where the Committee noted:
The ATO-
that is, the Australian Taxation Office-
emphasised the overall conservative nature of its estimates
The Committee went on to say:
The Committee acknowledges comments to this effect by the Joint Select Committee on an Australia Card, and the Auditor-General-
Senator Collins referred to both of those matters in his remarks earlier today-
and accepts that this may be so.

Whatever one may think of the proposals for a tax file number-and those proposals will be addressed when we come to debate the legislation-I do not believe there can be any reasonable doubt that such a device, if it were to be enacted, would result in a significant increase in revenue. The Committee and this Senate in due course will have to weigh the public interest in that revenue gain against the private cost of the potentially very considerable intrusions into personal privacy which might result from such an enactment. That will be the point of the future debate on this matter-not the question of whether or not the device would result in a significant increase in revenue.

I want also to say something about the second term of reference given us on 1 June, namely, the possibility of the tax file number scheme developing into a de facto national identification card system with unacceptable impositions upon privacy and civil liberties. The Committee has addressed this matter in a number of areas of chapter 10 of its report. In paragraph 10.5 the Committee says:
The Committee considers that there is a danger of any widely dispersed number-
that is, a tax file number-

becoming a de facto identification, notwithstanding provisions which prescribe penalties for improper use of the number. An examination of the overseas evidence . . . concerning limited use numbers supports this view.
I regard that as a very important conclusion. It is buttressed in paragraph 10.24, where the Committee says:
The Committee believes it is crucial that the strengthened privacy legislation foreshadowed by the Treasurer be in place . . .

Although the Committee does not elaborate upon what it means by the words `be in place', I have to say that `be in place' means that the privacy legislation has to be enacted by this Parliament and that the privacy commissioner, or whatever the authorised body may be under that legislation, has to be appointed, to have set up office and to be working. Paragraph 10.24 continues:
. . . no later than the implementation of the proposed tax file numbering scheme, and it has recommended accordingly.

That is a very significant finding, with a related recommendation, and one which I think has the most significant consequences for the timing of any proposed tax file number enactment, should that come to pass. Paragraph 10.26 contains the Committee's sole recommendation on this aspect of the terms of reference. The Committee says:
The Committee recommends that the Taxation Laws Amendment (Tax File Numbers) Bill 1988, if enacted-
the words which I stressed at the outset of my remarks-
be strictly limited in its terms so that it applies only in relation to taxation purposes and those purposes be so framed as to prevent a progressive extension of the ambit of the Bill.

The bottom line to the Senate's future and more deliberate consideration of this report in due course will be the question of the desirability or otherwise of the tax file number legislation which is currently before the Parliament, although it has not yet been debated in the other place.

I believe that the Senate Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs, under the very capable chairmanship of Senator Cooney and with the assistance of a hardworking and devoted staff, has produced a report which will be of assistance to the Senate in discussing that matter at the appropriate time. Nothing in this report suggests to me that the Committee has come out in favour of the tax file number proposal. If at the appropriate time the Opposition should take the view on the balance of all the considerations-the revenue gains and the tracking down of tax cheats on the one hand against the intrusions into personal privacy on the other-that it should oppose the tax file number legislation, I will certainly support that view, notwithstanding the fact that I, in common with most other members of this Committee, have found in this report that the tax file number system, if introduced, would indeed result in a significant increase in revenue.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Archer Sen B.R.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, upon notice, on 2 June 1988:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What percentage of foreign cheese consignments were tested for Listeria over the last five years.
(2) How many consignments were refused entry annually because of traces of Listeria over the same period.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Primary Industries and Energy has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Prior to November, 1987 the Commonwealth did not undertake any testing of imported cheeses for Listeria contamination. However, following overseas reports of the detection of Listeria monocytogenes in certain surface ripened cheeses and the significance of this for public health, procedures for testing susceptible cheeses were implemented under authority of the Quarantine Act.

Initial testing, which commenced in November 1987 comprised a spot check survey of an estimated 50% of susceptible cheeses imported. Subsequently, procedures were formalised from January, 1988 under which all cheese consignments from establishments implicated in the overseas reports or which showed failures when tested in Australia are sampled on arrival and detained until analysis has shown them to be clear of contamination. If contamination is found, the consignment is refused entry into Australia.

All other susceptible cheese imports are subject to random testing, but are not detained pending analysis. The rate of sampling for these cheeses is approximately 90%. If any contamination is found, State Health Departments and the Bureau of Consumer Affairs are advised so that recall action may be instituted. In the event of a contaminated consignment occurring, future shipments from the establishment concerned are subject to 100% sampling and detention pending clearance by analysis. Cheeses which are not susceptible to Listeria contamination are not tested under this program.

(2) Twelve of the one hundred and twenty-five samples from the November/December period were found to be contaminated with Listeria. Eleven of these had been released into distribution and State Departments of Health and the Federal Consumer Affairs Bureau were promptly advised to enable recall action to be initiated. The one consignment that had not been released was destroyed under Quarantine supervision at the importer's request. No further positive samples were detected until July this year when one consignment of cheese was found to contain a non-pathogenic strain of Listeria. No recall action was taken on this cheese, but another consignment found to contain pathogenic Listeria monocytogenes was refused entry into Australia. I am advised that most importers have stopped importing from companies implicated in the contamination incidents detected overseas or in the local testing program.
